loans.name: Bilqees' Group

texts.en:
Bilqees is the resident of Kamoki, which is a small industrial city also known for its rice and other agricultural crops. She lives in the area of Tiba mohammad nagar with her family in a 2-room brick house.

She is a very active lady who shares the financial burden with her husband by selling shawls (a kind of cloth, worn over the shoulders and body) and doing embroidery works. She receives embroidery orders from her neighboring clients and fulfills the orders on time to make an income.  

Her husband’s name is L. A. and he deals with rice. He has a shop in the market from where he operates his business of selling rice. He purchases them from the whole sale market on cheap rates and sells it on good profit. He has been doing this business for over 15 years.

Bilqees is the mother of 3 sons and 2 daughters. Her two elder sons are employed in a factory while the remaining 3 are enrolled in a school and are getting their education.

She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband’s business. With the loan, her husband will buy rice in bulk from wholesale market and earn a good return on it. She is very confident that her husband will be able to improve his business conditions with the help of the loan investment.

She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her 2nd loan application. In previous the loan year, she built good credit behavior and never missed any meetings.

Note: In the photo, the lady with a book (called Asasah Passbook) in her hands is Bilqees”.

loans.name: Nazri

texts.en:
Nazri is 63 years old and he has been married since the age of 26 to the mother of his 5 children. Nazri has worked in agriculture since he was a young. His father taught him how to responsibly work with each crop, and now, with the help of his wife and adult children, he feels a sense of dignity from his work. As a consequence, he treats each plant with affection and care until they are ready for harvest, at which point he takes them to sell in the market. Nazri would very much like to buy a house in the city to ensure the well-being and tranquility of his children, and in this way improve his quality of life. The money that Nazri is soliciting is to purchase seeds, chemical fertilizers, fuels and lubricants. Let’s support this hard-working and talented man so that he can obtain his goals!

loans.name: Mirzorahmad

texts.en:
S. Mirzorahmad is 49 years old, is married and lives with his wife and 8 children. He has been a farmer for the past 14 years, which he began with the goal of supporting his household and above all to satisfy the needs of his children. For Mirzorahmad, agriculture is an activity that he likes to do. Within it, vegetable production is what he likes most as it is easier to cultivate these plants and the product is profitable in season, which is annually. But the earnings are greater and beneficial for every farmer, especially when buyers purchase the product in great quantities and the expense of transporting the products is avoided as the buyers come to harvest and take them away themselves. Now Mirzorahmad wishes to borrow money, which he wants to invest in seeds, fertilizer, fuels and lubricants. He is sincerely grateful to all of you.

While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase seeds, mineral fertilizer, fuels and lubricants.

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
Beatrice has been practicing mixed farming for twelve years in Nkubu town, eastern Kenya. Her farm produces milk which she sells to a local dairy plant, and cabbages, carrots, tomatoes and potatoes which she sells to the local market. She also operates a small food kiosk in the same region. She says that her biggest challenges in farming have been the high cost of farm supplies and pests and diseases which affect her crops and animals.

Beatrice is 33 years old, and a married mother of four school-aged children who all attend school.

She has requested this loan of 31,200 KES through Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. The proceeds from this loan will help her pay school fees for her children, build a decent home for the family and improve their standard of living. She plans to increase the number of her dairy cows in the future and also venture into poultry farming. 

She comments that, compared to other institutions, she prefers Juhudi for its product features, especially the grace period on loans that Juhudi offers to clients (where clients are allowed to pay only interest for the first two months).

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Shamsudin

texts.en:
S. Shamsudin is an entrepreneur from Kumsangir, Southern Tajikistan. He runs a small business selling men’s clothing and shoes in one of the local markets. He started his business ten years ago. His business is characterized by stable expansion and profitability. Shamsudin is the only breadwinner in the family. He has to put much effort in this business to make it sustainable and profitable.

Shamsudin would like to receive a loan of $3000 to increase his inventory. Shamsudin has promptly repaid all loans from IMON International. We believe his integrity, responsibility and strong will can help him succeed and to repay the current loan without any problems. 

 
More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To buy new clothing in order to increase the range of goods

loans.name: Ganbold

texts.en:
Ganbold J. is 53 years old and lives with his wife in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. The couple lives together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. They have one daughter who lives on her own. 

Ganbold works as a taxi driver after operating a small grocery shop. Also, he repairs people's automobiles to supplement his income. He is planning on trading his car in for a new car. Since opening his business, he has been able to improve his family's quality of life, and his earnings have enabled him to purchase a new plot of land where he has been building a new house and fence for his family. 

Ganbold is requesting a 600,000 MNT loan in order to purchase necessary parts for his car.

loans.use: To purchase necessary parts for his car

loans.name: Erick

texts.en:
Erick is twenty-three years old and single. He is a dairy farmer from the town of Litein in Rift Valley, Kenya. He has been farming for three years and employs one farmhand. He sells his milk to the local market and to a nearby tea estate. He also earns income from his small-scale farming of tea, which he sells through Kenya Tea Development Authority, and eggs which he sells to the local market. His major challenges have been the poor transport network to the market, lack of good artificial insemination services and lack of knowledge on animal feeds and diseases.

Erick has requested this loan from Juhudi Kilimo of 35,000 KES to purchase and insure a dairy cow. He says that the project will help increase his income and he will be able to plan for his future before getting married. He plans to build a dairy unit in the future and increase the number of his dairy cows to five.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Mehmonboy

texts.en:
V. Mehmonboy is a simple farmer with simple dreams – to improve his family’s economic life and to be able to send his dear children to University in the future. 

Farming has been his major source of income. He grows different kinds of vegetables and also raises cattle. Now he is requesting a loan of $2,200 to support his farming business and to avoid asking for credit from traders charging higher interest. He is grateful that he was able to borrow from a lender that offers lower interest rates and creates better opportunities in their lives. This will help their family to be free from poverty.

Mehmonboy said that through prayers and hard work, his dreams can be achieved someday. Providing his children with education is one of the important things that Mehmonboy prioritizes.

loans.use: To purchase seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Jameela's Group

texts.en:
Jameela lives in the small city of Khanewal, which is located in Pakistan and known for its agriculture industry. She has been living in an area of this city called Ahmed nagar for the last twenty-four years in a two-room brick house.  

She is married to S. A. who runs a grocery business. He has a small grocery store in the market where he sells daily use items like cooking oil, rice, lentils, spices and other edible items like biscuits, chips and candies.  

She has three daughters and two sons. All of them are enrolled in a school and are getting their education, except the eldest one who helps his father in his business. He didn’t show interest in school and left his studies after completing eight grades.  

Jameela herself is a housewife. She stays at home and takes care of her household responsibilities. She is a very active lady who is always ready to improve the family's standard of living.
  
She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner, Asasah, for her husband’s business. With the loan, he will buy the grocery items in bulk quantities and increase his sales. He has been in this business for many years and Jameela is hopeful that this investment will move her husband’s business into a more profitable position.  She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her 3rd loan application. She has maintained a good credit record in previous loan years and attended every meeting.  

Note: In the photo, the lady who has a book in her hands (called Asasah Passbook) is Jameela.

loans.use: To buy groceries for grocery shop

loans.name: Shamshad's Group

texts.en:
Shamshad is a very supportive lady. She always remains ready to support her family in every way possible. She operates her sewing business at her home to support her family in fulfilling their basic needs. She also sells goats as her second business. She buys them from the animal market, raises them up and sells for a good profit. Besides her businesses, she is also a very good housewife and a very caring mother. She is rearing her five children very well. Her husband is a daily-wage laborer.
   
Shamshad has applied for a loan from the Kiva partner, Asasah, for her business of selling goats. With the loan she will buy goats to expand her business.  She is hopeful that this investment will help her to make a good profit, which she will use for the education of her children.  She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her 3rd loan application. She is a responsible client and fulfills her duties responsibly.  
 
She lives with her family in a two-room brick house in a small city named Khanewal in Pakistan. Khanewal is famous for its agriculture industry.  

Note: In the photo, Shamshad is the lady who is holding a book (called the Asasah Passbook) in her hands.

loans.use: To buy goats for reselling

loans.name: Mao

texts.en:
Mrs. Mao K. is a 46-year-old single mother living in a village in Kompong Chhnang Province. She doesn’t have a life partner as her husband divorced her when her child was very small. Mrs. Mao K. has only one child, who is a garment worker and has a proper salary. 

She owns a piece of farmland that she inherited over ten years ago from her grandparents. She uses this land to grow different kinds of crops. She planted rice and vegetable crops three months ago, but her crops are not growing well because they need more fertilizer. To remedy the situation, she would like a loan to buy some sacks of fertilizer for improving her crops.

loans.use: To buy sacks of fertilizer for improving her crop

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buying a car for transport business

loans.name: Rhoda

texts.en:
Rhoda C. is from the village of Tabo-o, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. She is 57 years old. Rhoda is married and has nine adult children. To make a living, Rhoda owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Rhoda has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Rhoda joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rhoda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used as additional capital for her business. Rhoda is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be the fourth loan taken out by Rhoda from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en: Elizabeth is a 31-year-old lady, married with one child. She lives in Fort Portal, Uganda in a rented house. She has a retail shop business which has been in existence for two years now.  Elizabeth also sells air time in her business and says she would like to become an agent for one of the telecommunications companies around her. This is Elizabeth’s first loan from HOFOKAM and she intends to purchase air time to sell in her shop.

loans.use: Purchasing air time to sell in her shop

loans.name: Imtiaz's Group

texts.en:
Imtiaz is a resident of the small city of Khanewal and has lived there for many years with her family in a two-room brick house in the area named Ahmed nagar.  She is a housewife. She prefers to stay at home and do her household work, but a few years ago she started an animal selling business. She bought some goats, raised them up and sold them to the butchers for a profit. It earned her a very handsome income and she became an earning helper for her family. She has now adopted this business as a profession. It helps her to manage her household expenses better. She is the mother of three sons and two daughters. All of them are enrolled in school and are getting their education, except the youngest one who is just three years old.

Imtiaz has applied for a loan from the Kiva partner, Asasah, for her husband’s furniture making business. With the loan money, her husband will buy items such as nails, wood and wood polish in bulk quantities, which will enable him to make more furniture to sell. Imtiaz is hopeful that her husband's business will grow further by utilizing the loan money. She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her 2nd loan application. She is a responsible client and fulfills her duties responsibly.   

Note: In the photo, Imtiaz is the lady who has a book in her hands (called Asasah Passbook).

loans.use: To buy items for furniture making business

loans.name: Alice

texts.en:
Alice, 46, lives in Fort Portal, Uganda. She is a businesswoman, married with seven children. Her family is comprised of 14 people and they own a family house. Her major dreams for the family are education for the children and also improving household income. 

Alice operates a retail shop and has been in the business for five years now. She says fluctuation of prices affects her business operations due to interference with planned purchases and selling prices of commodities. Alice says she wants to see her retail shop transformed into a wholesale one in the near future. Alice intends to use the loan proceeds to pay school fees for the children.

loans.use: Paying school fees for her children.

loans.name: Lyndamar

texts.en:
Lyndamar C. is from the village of Tabo-o, Jimenez. She is 28 years old. Lyndamar is married and has two very young children. To make a living, Lyndamar owns & operates a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Lyndamar has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Lyndamar joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lyndamar is requesting a loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the first loan taken out by Lyndamar from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Sakina's Group

texts.en:
Sakina lives in Khanewal which is a small city located in Pakistan and known for its agriculture industry. She owns a 2 room brick house there and lives in it with her family. She moved here after she got married with M. I.. 

Sakina is a seam-stress. She sews clothes for her neighboring clients and generates income for the family. She is good at her art and receives regular orders. Her husband has a business operating a grocery store. His store is located in the market where he deals with good number of customers every day.  

Sakina has given birth to 3 sons and a daughter. All of them are enrolled in school and getting their education except the eldest son who left after the 5th grade because he didn’t show any interest in education. He works in a factory for a monthly wage and supports the family from his earnings.    

Sakina has applied for a loan from Kiva partnerAsasah, to financially assist her husband with his grocery store business. With the loan, he will buy groceries in bulk quantity which helps him increase his business. She is hopeful that her husband will make his business better after this loan investment. Sakina is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her 2nd loan application.  She is a responsible client and fulfills her duties responsibly.  

Note: “In the photo, the lady who has holds a book (called Asasah Passbook) in her hands is Sakina”.

loans.use: To buy groceries for a grocery store business

loans.name: Kuli

texts.en: Kuli is married and has two children. He makes a living selling fruit at the food market of Istaravshan. His location is very good and he serves many customers because he is willing to work late. Kuli has been in this business for 10 years and knows a good deal about it. Kuli is also a very punctual and detail-oriented person, character traits that help him in his business. Kuli can always figure out how many supplies he needs so there is enough on hand to meet customer needs and it is always fresh. Kuli has applied for a loan to increase his inventory of items to sell. He will spend the additional income made possible by this loan to improve his living conditions.

loans.use: Increasing of the variety of fruit to sell

loans.name: Jeff

texts.en:
Jeff M. is from the village of Rizal, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. He is 26 years old. Jeff is single. To make a living, Jeff offers transportation services. Jeff has been engaged in his business for over a year and earns approximately 2,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Jeff joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jeff is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase tires and other accessories. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Jeff from GDMPC. 

He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of the borrower's family. 

About GDMPC:

loans.use: to purchase tires and other accessories

loans.name: Pel

texts.en:
Pel N. is a 56-year-old married man and father. He lives with other family members in his own small family home in Kompong Chhnang Province. His wife is also helps him in this field. The couple is married and have two children. He owns a piece of land that he inherited from his grandmother. Pel grows different kinds of crop on his land, such as cabbage and morning glorys. 

Pel N. has also raised a few of piglets and he had hoped to sell them to buyers three months after he began raising them. Unfortunately, the pigs are not big enough, due to the lack of food. To help solve this problem, San Naun has requested a loan that he will use to buy many sacks of pig feed to fatten his pigs. He will use the rest of the loan towards purchasing more pigs.

loans.use: To buy sacks of pig feed to fatten his pigs. He will use rest of the loan towards purchasing more pigs.

loans.name: Moses

texts.en:
Moses is a young man aged 22 years, living in Fort Portal, Uganda. He looks after a family of four people in a family house. Moses is a farmer and is also into the motorcycle transport business and has operated it for the last five years. He got the capital to buy a motorcycle from the profit he earned as a farmer. 

As a farmer, Moses says that price fluctuations and weather changes are his major challenges. He says he hopes to become an advanced farmer dealing mostly in cash crops. The purpose of the loan is to enable Moses to pay labor to clear his farmland for cultivation and also to plant onions.

loans.use: Paying labor to clear his farmland

loans.name: Jessica

texts.en:
Jessica B. is from the village of Tabo-o, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. She is 41 years old. Jessica is married and has four grown children. To make a living, Jessica owns & operates a fishing business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and selling fish in the local community. Jessica has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Jessica joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jessica has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to build capital for her business. 

Jessica is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional fish to sell. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Jessica from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.name: Khusnidin

texts.en:
Khusnidin is a hard-working entrepreneur from Istaravshan, Tajikistan. He owns a small market vending business where he sells clothes and shoes. Khusnidin decided to start his own business after he was unable to find other work. Because of difficult living condition his sons had to leave for Russia to earn money. Currently the business of Khusnidin is the main source of income for his large family. 

He has requested a loan of 7500 Somoni to purchase some new inventory for his business. Khusnidin will use profits from his business to improve his standard of living and do some remodeling to his home. He dreams of opening another two vending places for his sons.

loans.use: Purchase new clothing in order to increase the variety of goods for sale.

loans.name: Andrew

texts.en:
Andrew is a businessman based in Fort Portal, Uganda. He is aged 37 years, married to a peasant wife and together they have four children. He looks after a family of six people who all live in his own house. He wants to see his children attain quality education for a better future. 

Andrew operates a retail shop in which he sells domestic items such as cooking oil, sugar, salt, and other foodstuffs and it has been in operation for the last seven years. He says that bad debtors affect his cash flow projections so he would like to transform the business into a wholesale shop. Andrew intends to use the loan proceeds to pay school fees for his children.

loans.use: Paying school fees for the children

loans.name: Ryan Jay

Ryan Jay D. is from the village of Tabo-o, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. He is 27 years old. Ryan Jay is married and has two infant-aged children. To make a living, Ryan Jay operates a fishing business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling fish caught in the ocean within the local community. Ryan Jay has been engaged in his business for over three years and earns approximately 1,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Ryan Jay joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ryan Jay is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fishing equipment including hooks and nets. 

This loan will be the first loan taken out by Ryan Jay from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the borrower's business.

loans.name: Wensi

texts.en: Wensi is a 26-year-old man living in Fort Portal, Uganda. He is into the business of poultry and has been in it for the last year. He says that he started it with a few chicks but now, it has grown with a considerable increase in the number of chickens he has. He says the only challenge is that poultry is a demanding business which needs capital to inject so as to meet the ever changing quality requirements. He would love to see himself becoming a national supplier of chicken. The purpose of the loan facility is to enable Wensi to buy chicks and chicken feed for his poultry farm.

loans.use: Buying chicks and chicken feed for his poultry farm

loans.name: Nida

texts.en:
Nida S. is from the village of Katipunan, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. She is 38 years old. Nida is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Nida operates a clothing business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from providing new clothing to local community members. Nida has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month for these activities.

loans.name: Marivonne

texts.en:
This is Marivonne Lamberte, 38, resident of Caloocan City, Philippines. She is married to Edgardo Lamberte, an overseas Filipino worker, and mother of two youngsters currently enrolled in elementary school. By the grace of God, Marivonne has managed to support her children's schooling. At this time, she is working hard to send both of her children all the way through college. A dream for most Filipino parents like Marivonne, as she herself has been a college undergraduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents could leave to their children.

Marivonne operates a retail business. What she basically does is buy general merchandise from wholesalers then sells them piecemeal with a little profit. Products can range from furniture to household appliances, electronic devices, clothing and other products of the like. Customers are attracted to buy due to the low selling prices and the many options they are offered. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of Php200 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php11, 000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities and varieties of products to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 
 
Marivonne dreams to be able to give all her children a good and high quality education through all her hard work on her business. She also hopes to have her house renovated by the end of the year. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: buy more quantities and varieties of products to expand her product inventory.

loans.name: Fe

texts.en:
This is Fe G., 41, resident of Caloocan City, Philippines. She is married to Gerry G., an employee of a printing business, and mother of four children, all of whom are already in high school. By the grace of God, Fe has managed to support her children's schooling. At this time, she is working hard to be able to send all of them all the way through college. A dream for most Filipino parents like Fe, as she herself has been a college undergraduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents could leave to their children.

Fe maintains a direct selling business. She sells clothing, footwear, undergarments, cosmetics and other products through the popular direct selling brands like Avon, Fullerlife, Natasha, Boardwalk, Marikina Shoe Exchange, and other direct selling brands. A customers order is bought in cash by the dealer and then given to the customer with a one-month-to-pay credit. Dealer’s prices are lower than those in the catalogue, and these are the profits that dealers are investing on as their income. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of Php2000 in sales every week.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php14, 000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy orders for her customers. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 
 
Fe dreams to be able to give all her children a good and high quality education through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.name: Ulugbek

texts.en:
A. Ulugbek is 38 years old. He is married with two children. He has a great passion for dairy farming and has been in this business for 6 years together with his wife. Ulugbek would like to expand his business by adding more cattle to the ones he has. This is because recently he acquired orders from outside town to supply milk. He is requesting a loan of 5900 Somoni. With additional income Ulugbek will be better able to cater for his family financial obligations, especially the education of his children.   


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.name: Yolanda

texts.en:
This is Yolanda T., a resident of Caloocan City, Philippines. She is 53 years old, married to Jose T., a retired pensioner, and is the mother to five hardworking young adults. By the grace of God, Melitona has managed to support her children's schooling up to college level. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.
Yolanda operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go for to buy one sachet of shampoo, 5 PHP-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. Yolanda earns a living by purchasing supplies at wholesale prices and selling them at piece rates. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and members of the local community. She earns a minimum of 200 PHP in sales every day.
To help her continue to operate her business, she is requesting a loan of 11, 000 PHP. She will use the loan to buy more products like groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.
Yolanda dreams of renovating her house soon, with the profits from all of her work. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week. * All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

Olimboy, along with his wife, has 15 years of experience in raising cattle and selling dairy products. He also provides taxi services in his car in his free time.
Olimboy's milk products are in very high demand in his village. His orders for these products are very high but the milk his cows give is not enough so he has decided to apply for a loan of $1,500 USD to purchase additional cows and fodder for them. Olimboy is very grateful to everyone who is helping him to improve his life with this loan.

More about Tajikistan
Tajikistan, a key post on the Silk Road, is perhaps best known for its rich history. It was the location for the end of Alexander the Great's rule, and is known for its great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets such as Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country, with its epic mountain passes, is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language and a civilization that dates back to the fourth millennium BC. Even today, it is a complex mix of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

However, Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the USSR, damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93 per cent of the country is mountainous and only 7 per cent of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands of people to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

loans.name: Paul

texts.en:
Paul is 57 years old. He is married with 14 children who are between the ages of 17 and 34. Three of his children are currently attending school. Paul is a farmer from Kisii town in western Kenya. He has been farming for 30 years and employs four farmhands. His mixed farm produces maize, sugarcane and nappier grass, which he sells to the local market. He also operates a butchery in the same location. His biggest challenges are lack of sufficient funds to expand his business and drought, which affects his sugarcane production.
Paul has requested a loan of 40,000 KES from Kiva partner, Juhudi Kilimo, to purchase and insure a dairy cow. This dairy cow will enable him to provide enough milk for domestic consumption and sale. The extra income from the sale of milk will help him pay school fees for his children. In the future, he would like to expand his dairy farming by adding more quality dairy cows.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase bags of cement for resale

loans.name: Paul Kiprop

texts.en:
Paul Kiprop N. is 45 years old and married to Jane Kurgat, a housewife. They have three children aged 2, 5 and 8. They live in Nyeny-Kwen, Eldoret, Kenya. Paul operates a dairy farm and has been in this business for ten years. He earns a monthly profit of 15,000 KES.
Paul learned about Kiva partner, KADET, through marketing awareness done in the area. He is applying for his third loan, of 35,000 KES, from KADET, which he intends to use to buy two dairy cows. With the anticipated profits, he plans to buy a motorbike for another business.
In the future, Paul wishes to have a pick-up to transport animal feed. His deeper desire is to see his children realize their goals in life through better education.

loans.use: To buy two dairy cows

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to expand his business and purchase more vegetables and fruit

loans.name: Jessica Len's Group

texts.en:
Jessica Len J. is from the village of San Pablo, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is 28 years old. Jessica Len is the group leader of a 8-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Jessica Len is married and has one school-aged child. To make a living, Jessica Len owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector selling agricultural equipment. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling animal feed & mash to local farmers. Jessica Len has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Jessica Len joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jessica Len has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Jessica Len is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional agricultural equipment to sell. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Jessica Len from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional agricultural equipment to sell

loans.name: Noel

texts.en:
Noel P. is from the village of Gata Daku, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. He is 38 years old. Noel is single. To make a living, Noel owns & operates a service-based business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from providing photocopy services to local community members. Noel has been engaged in his business for over 10 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2003, Noel joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Noel has successfully repaid a previous loan of 45,000 PHP from GDMPC. Noel is requesting a new loan of 45,000 PHP which will be used to purchase materials needed to expand services provided. This will be the 17th loan taken out by Noel from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase materials needed to expand services provided

loans.name: Donald

texts.en:
Donald R. is from the village of Lapasan, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. He is 29 years old. Donald is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Donald owns & operates transportation services. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from operating these services. Donald has been engaged in his business for over one year and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Donald joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Donald has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from GDMPC. Donald is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to repair existing vehicle for better service. This will be the fourth loan taken out by Donald from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to repair existing vehicle for better service

loans.name: Peter Maina

texts.en:
Peter Maina M. is 45 years old and married to Mwendwa. They have three children. He has a retail shop that he has been running for one year with a profit of approximately KES 14000 per month.

He intends to use the loan to re-stock his shop with shopping bags, tire rubber, soaps, detergent, sodas and tea leaves. He has never borrowed from another MFI and this is his third loan from KADET Ltd., where he has been successfully repaying the previous ones. 

He hopes to expand his business and buy a piece of land and develop it in order to improve his family's standard of living.

loans.use: To re-stock his shop

loans.name: Janbolat

texts.en:
Janbolat H. is 35 years old and lives with his wife and two young children in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent home, in the Bayan-Ulgiy province of western Mongolia. His wife is unemployed and stays at home with their children. 

Janbolat operates a transportation business. He started his business in 2004 with his own big truck. He transports people's loads between Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia's capital city, and Tashkeshtan, China's border city. Janbolat has also begun to supplement his transportation service earnings by transporting and selling coal in the local community. He purchases one ton of coal for 35000 MNT from the countryside, transports it 150 km and and sells it at the local market for 50000 MNT. His large Russian truck consumes a lot of petrol, which is very costly. Because of that, his transportation business has not reached a sustainable level yet. 

Janbolat is a very open-minded and hardworking man. He says, " I want to save enough money and build a big house for my family." He is requesting a 2000000 MNT loan to purchase six tires for his truck.

loans.use: To purchase tires for his truck

loans.name: Primo

texts.en:
Primo P. is from Oroquieta City. He is 27 years old. Primo is single. To make a living, Primo owns & operates transportation services. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from operating these services. Primo has been engaged in his business for over two years and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Primo joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Primo has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from GDMPC. Primo is requesting a new loan of 50,000 PHP which will be used to repair existing vehicle for better service. This will be the tenth loan taken out by Primo from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to repair existing vehicle for better service

loans.name: Lourdes

texts.en:
Lourdes S. is from the village of Poblacion 2, Clarin, Misamis Occ. She is 62 years old. Lourdes is married and has five adult children. To make a living, Lourdes owns & operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling personal products in the local community. Lourdes has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 7000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2006, Lourdes joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lourdes has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,000 PHP from GDMPC. Lourdes is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the ninth loan taken out by Lourdes from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Myagmarsuren

texts.en:
Myagmarsuren C. is 41 years old and lives with her husband in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of  Mongolia. She and her husband live in their own ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent home. Her husband operates a transportation service to supplement his family income. 

Myagmarsuren has been operating a retail shoe business in a rented stall at Harhorin trade market in the city since 2004 and has built a stable operation. She works hard to continue running her business. She says, "All I want is to operate this business successfully so that we can afford to buy an apartment in the future." 

She is requesting a 2000000 MNT loan to purchase a large quantity of shoes before the winter months. Those goods are rarely available between November and March.

loans.use: To purchase a large quantity of shoes

loans.name: Hiram Ndungu

texts.en:
Hiram is 32 years old and married to Lucy Wairumu. They have one child of three years. He has a retail shop that he has been running for a period of about three years with a profit of approximately 14,800 Kenyan shillings per month.

He intends to use the loan to restock his shop with maize flour, sugar, soaps, detergent, sodas and tea leaves. He has never borrowed from another MFI (microfinance institution) and this is his fourth loan from KADET LTD. He has been successfully repaying the previous ones. 

He hopes to expand his business and buy a piece of land to develop in order to improve his family's standard of living.

loans.use: To buy stock of maize flour, sugar, soaps, detergent, sodas and tea leaves

loans.name: Hasina's Group

texts.en:
Hasina is a very caring lady by nature. She takes care of her family by staying at home and preparing delicious food for them and fulfilling their needs. She is always ready to help her family in difficult times. 

She lives in Khanewal, which is a small city located in Pakistan, with her husband, three sons and a brother-in-law in a combined family system. Only her eldest son is able to attend school due to financial constraints. He is studying in 4th class. 

Hasina’s husband is a laborer and he works on daily wages. 

She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah to help her brother-in-law, who is involved in an animal sales business. With the loan, he will buy young animals (goats and cows), raise them and then sell them to his customers at a profit. His clientele base is butchers.  

Hasina is confident that her brother-in-law will utilize the loan money in a positive manner and improve his business condition. She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her second loan application. She is a responsible client and fulfills her duties responsibly. 
 
Note: In the photo, the lady who has is holding the book (called Asasah Passbook) in her hands is Hasina.

loans.use: To buy animals (goats and cows) for an animal sales business

loans.name: Bernard Gitimu

texts.en:
Bernard is 32 years old and married to Jane Nyaguthii. He has a horticulture farm. He sells his products to distributors in the area. He has been in the business for a period of about one year. 

He intends to buy  fertilizers and fungicides for his crops. He has never been in another MFI (microfinance institution) and this is his third loan after repaying the previous ones successfully. He hopes to have his children get through school and to buy land to start dairy farming.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and fungicides

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma is a married woman with five children. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For over 10 years, she has operated an open-air food selling business from home, with neighbors being her potential customers. Fatuma faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. During the winter rainy season it becomes difficult for her to sell at an open-air market. She hopes to open a restaurant in the future.

She decided to join Yehu to get loans to boost her business. With the 20,000 Kenyan shillings, she wants to purchase wheat flour, sugar, cooking oil and paraffin.

loans.use: To purchase wheat flour, sugar, cooking oil and paraffin

loans.name: Shafiqullah

texts.en: Shafiqullah is son of F. R.. He is a resident of Kabul, Afghanistan. He is married and the father of three children. He needs the loan to purchase house construction supplies and build a new room because his house is very small and two rooms are not enough for his family to live in.Shafiqullah hopes that through this loan process he can solve the problem of his family.

loans.use: to purchase house construction supplies

loans.name: Namhaijamts

texts.en:
Namhaijamts S. is 38 years old and lives with his wife and two daughters in Ulaanbaatar, a capital city of Mongolia. His daughter, Munhjargal, is 11 years old and attends a local secondary school and his wife, who works in the Mongolian Post company, has recently given a birth to a baby and is on her maternity leave. He and his family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. 

Before moving to Ulaanbaatar, the family had lived in the Gobi-Altai province till 2000 and they operated a shoe-making business in their town. 

Namhaijamts operates a coal-selling business by transporting coal from the nearest coal mine in Ulaanbaatar. He purchases coal directly from local mine and uses his large van to transport it back to the city. He has been engaged in this business since 2004 after purchasing a car and has gained much experience over the years. He has a large customer base with many loyal clients. He made a contract with the police departments of Songinohairhan district to supply them coal. For the future, he hopes to buy a truck with a high hauling capacity. 

Namhaijamts is requesting a 1,500,000 Mongolian tugriks loan for his coal-transportation business.

loans.use: To use in his coal-transportation business

loans.name: Sughran's Group

texts.en:
Sughran (who we see here holding a blue book) is a housewife who is always ready to help her husband, who makes a living selling fruits.  Her husband buys his fruits in a wholesale market and sells them to people in his community from a four-wheeled cart. Sughran helps him by getting up early in the morning to arrange items on the cart. She knows that her husband works really hard to put three meals on the table for his family, and that’s why she is committed to help him and care for him.   

Sughran and her husband have three sons. The oldest makes a living selling milk and yogurt from a shop in the local market and the other two are still in school. She has applied for a loan which her husband will use to buy fresh seasonal fruits in bulk from wholesale markets. She believes that this loan will help her husband earn more money and operate his business more efficiently. 

For the last nine years, Sughran and her family have lived in a two-room brick house in a small city named Khanewal. She is a member of Asasah and this is her third loan request. She paid her previous loans on time.

loans.use: To buy fresh fruits to sell to her customers

loans.name: Herbert

texts.en: Herbert L. is 36 years old, married and has two children, who are 10 and five years old. He and his wife hope to give their children a good education, including a chance to go to college. Herbert runs a store in Kakamega, a part of Kenya known for production of sugar cane. He sells items such as sugar, fats and oils, flour, rice, detergents, paraffin and other items to people who live in his area. He has been in this business for the last three years and is making a profit, but his income is not as large as he would like because his customers are mostly poor people. Still, he works very hard and has applied for this loan to buy more items to sell to his customers. In the future, he hopes to increase his income by opening a wholesale business.

loans.use: To buy more items to sell to his customers

loans.name: Layal

texts.en: Layal is 26 years old, married and has made a living decorating souvenirs since 2007. She is applying for a loan from All Majmoua to buy more of the supplies she needs to operate and expand her business. Her clients are brides, pregnant mothers and anyone with a special occasion to celebrate. Layal has lots of experience in this area and is very talented. She hopes to expand her business and open a larger store in the future.

loans.use: To buy the supplies she needs to run her business

loans.name: Janet

texts.en:
Janet P. is 31 years old and lives in Silang, Cavite City, Philippines. She is married to Filbert P., who makes a living as a painter, and has two children who are both in elementary school. By the grace of God, she has managed to help pay for her children's schooling and meet her family's everyday expenses.

Janet operates a small convenience store where she sells groceries, toiletries and beverages to people who live in her neighborhood. Her store is located next to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the people who live in her community.  She earns a minimum of Php 300 in sales every day.

She has applied for a loan for PHP 15,000 to continue operating her business by buying more items to sell to her customers. She is confident that this loan will give her business a boost and increase her income. She hopes to use this additional income to renovate her house. She is a devoted member of CCT and faithfully attends all of our meetings to share information and tips on how to succeed in business

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners who meet to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay mocrofinance loans.

loans.use: to buy more items to sell to her customers

loans.name: Tsetsegee

texts.en: Tsetsegee U. is a 57-year-old widow who lives with her two daughters and two grandchildren in a ger or a traditional Mongolian tent in the Songinohairhan district of Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia. Tsetsegee has earned a living by making a variety of knitted and woven products in her home since 2005, when she bought the equipment needed to knit professionally. Her two daughters help her with her work. She produces all kind of clothes made from camel and yak wools. Currently, her business is expanding and she has applied for a loan to buy more equipment and tools. Tsegsegee is a hard-working and honest person and says, "I hope to continue running my business so that I can build houses for my two daughters." She is requesting a loan for 1,200,000 MNT  to buy the knitting machine she needs to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy a knitting machine

loans.name: Ngin

texts.en:
Ngin S. has been a farming businesswoman for a long time. She lives in the province of Kompong Chhnang. Since 1990, Ngin S. has owned and operated her farm to cultivate a rice crop, from which she earns a daily income. Ngin S., 37, is married to Sokon, 40, who is a local construction builder. Ngin S. has three children, one of whom is married and lives independently while the two remaining are single. 

In the past, Ngin S. hired farmer’s cow to help plow her farmland. She hopes to reduce her farm expenses by using her Kiva loan to buy a pair of cows for plowing.

loans.use: To buy a pair of cows for plowing

loans.name: Irshad's Group

texts.en:
Irshad resides in Khanewal which is a small city located in Punjab province of Pakistan and known for its agriculture industry. She lives there in a 2-room brick house with her family. She is a widow and lost her husband a few years ago as a result of sudden death. It was a very difficult time for her but she never loses hope. She recovered her senses and started working in her husband’s fields along with her eldest son. She has worked very hard to raise her children. 

Now, as her eldest son has grown up, she no longer works. She stays at home and does her household chores. She has 4 sons and none of them were able to go to school because of financial constraints. 

She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her eldest son. With the loan, her son will start selling fertilizer & seeds. As Khanewal city is famous for its agriculture, people have their own land and grow crops on their farmland. Her son is quite hopeful that through his new business he can sell these farm supply items to more people which will make more profit and his new business will become a good source of earning for his family. 

Irshad is a new loan user of Asasah and this is her 1st loan application.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer & seeds to resell

loans.name: Rosalinda

texts.en:
This is Rosalinda V., 46, resident of Silang, Cavite City, Philippines. She is married to an aircraft maintenance man and mother to their three children, one of whom is already working. By the grace of God, Rosalinda has managed to support her children's schooling. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Rosalinda operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go for to buy one sachet of shampoo, a Php5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns profit by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling retail.  Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of Php300 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php30,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities of products like groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her income as she expands her business.
  
Rosalinda dreams of being able to renovate her house soon, with all of her work with the business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: buy more groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory

loans.name: Clarita

texts.en:
Clarita J. is 62-year-old married woman and supports her family by operating one business venture: a firewood retailing business.  She lives in Purok Caimito, Brgy. Tacup, San Remegio, Cebu. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2008 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts.

By working hard in her firewood retailing business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 7,000. Clarita is now borrowing PHP 10,000 so that she can continue to fund the operations of her firewood sales.   This will be her 5th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 10,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. 

Clarita aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the  Dungganon way. 

About NWTF: 

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Fund the operations of selling firewood and coconuts

loans.name: Bat-Undrah

texts.en:
Bat-Undrah D. is 29 years old and lives with her husband and two children in a house in the Baganuur, one of the remote districts of Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia's capital city. Both of her children attend secondary school while her husband operates a carpentry and construction business to supplement his family's income. 

Bat-Undrah manages a cafe in a rented space close to the road where she can attract a large number of customers. She has been engaged in this business since 2009 with one employee to help her. Before starting her own cafe, she used to work as a cook in the Tugs Tuguldur cafe. She plans to expand her cafe and therefore is requesting a 2,000,000 MNT loan in order to purchase necessary equipment such as a freezer, a refrigerator with a glass door, and a stove for her cafe, and also decorate her cafe.

loans.use: To purchase necessary equipment

loans.name: Zubaida's Group

texts.en:
Zubaida is married to M. B. who has a grocery store business in the market where he deals with many customers every day and sells them the groceries they need. She lives with her family in a city named Khanewal in a 2-room brick house. Khanewal is a small city in Pakistan known for its agriculture industry. 

Zubaida doesn’t have any children, so she spends her time staying at home and doing her household responsibilities. Her brother also lives with her and works in the fields. He grows seasonal crops in their fields and earns good income on it. He contributes financially to Zubaida’s family from his earnings. 

Zubaida has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband’s business. With the loan, her husband will buy groceries in bulk quantities and increase his sales. He started this business 2 years ago and Zubaida is hopeful that this investment will bring better profits for her husband’s business. 

She is a new loan applicant and hopes that it will be a profitable experience for her. 

Note: In the photo, the lady holding a book (called Asasah Passbook) in her hands is Zubaida.

loans.use: To buy groceries for grocery store business

loans.name: Daisy

texts.en:
This is Daisy B., 30, resident of Silang, Cavite, Philippines. She is married to Napoleon B., Jr. and mother to their only child. By the grace of God, Daisy has managed to support her child. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Daisy operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go for to buy one sachet of shampoo, a Php5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling them at a piece rate.  Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of Php300 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php 14,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.
  
Daisy dreams of being able to renovate her house soon, with all of her work with the business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: buy more groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory

loans.name: Gulomhaydar

texts.ru: Зикиров Гуломхайдар проживает в районе Хамадони. Возраст, 58 лет. Женат, имеет 5 детей. Жена, домохозяйка. Двое сыновей живут и занимаются бизнесом в городе Душанбе. Сам Гуломхайдар имеет средне - специальное образование, художник. По специальности работает уже 25 лет. Кредит берет для приобретения красок и других, необходимых для деятельности вещей.
texts.en: Gulomhaydar Z. lives in the Hamadoni district.  He is 58 years old, married and has 5 children.  His wife is a homemaker.  Two of their sons live and do business in the city of Dushanbe.  Gulomhaydar has a secondary-specialized education, as an artist.  He has been working in his field for 25 years.  He is requesting this loan for the purchase of paint and other essentials for the business.

loans.use: Purchase of paint and other essentials for the business

loans.name: Jovelyn

texts.en:
Jovelyn S. is from the town of Sto. Niño. She is 40 years old. Jovelyn is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Jovelyn grows and sells rice, which is her main source of income. Jovelyn has been farming for over 16 years.

Jovelyn joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Jovelyn has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Jovelyn is requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP, which will be used to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm materials. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: To purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm materials

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy more clothing to sell to his customers

loans.name: Irshaad's Group

texts.en:
Irshaad is 41 years old and married to A. S., who is a laborer by profession and works for a daily wage. A.'s income is not guaranteed every day because he doesn’t always get work from the building constructors. Their eldest son helps support the family financially from his grocery store business. He is a very hard worker and very responsible as well. He is completely aware off his responsibilities, which is why A. feels proud of him, that he has become a supporter and earning hand of the family at a very young age. 

Irshaad has given birth to 4 sons and 2 daughters. The rest of A.'s siblings are enrolled in a local school and are getting their education. Irshaad is a very caring lady. She prefers to stay at home and carry out her responsibilities as a housewife.  

She has applied for a loan from the Kiva partner Asasah for her son’s grocery store business. With the loan, he will be able to purchase grocery items in bulk for his store to meet the demand of his customers. He has been in this business for over 10 years and Irshaad is hopeful that this investment will help her son’s business grow and he will make better profits. 

She is a new loan applicant of Asasah and is confident that this will convert to a long term relationship. Irshaad is the lady in the photo who is holding the book (called Asasah Passbook).

loans.use: To buy grocery items for grocery store business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase a television, movies and hair chemicals for his barber shop.

loans.name: Hem

texts.en: Hem S. is a village woman and a widow- her husband died of senility a few years ago. She is a local farmer in Kompong Chhnang Province. She plants various crops to earn a living and typically generates an income of $5 per day. She has three teen-aged children, two of whom are single and a third that is employed in a public organization. Kong S. is able to plant the crops at least twice a year by following both rainy and dry seasons. Growing crops is an annual action with which she has had great success. The coming rainfall is good, however, Hem S. doesn’t have capital yet to use on her farm. So, Hem S. is looking for a loan to use towards purchasing fertilizers and a pump machine.

loans.use: To use towards purchasing fertilizers and a pump machine.

loans.name: Urther

texts.en: Urther I. M. is fifty-one years old and married to a business woman. They have four children between the ages of twenty-five and fifteen and they hope to be able to send their children to school through the university level. Urther's business is located in Kakamega. Kakamega is a region in Kenya, known for the production of sugar cane and widely referred to as the sugar belt region. He sells plastic containers and basins to the local people. He has been in this business for the last five years. He says that this business is profitable and the major challenge he has is that there are many other people in the area operating the same kind of business as his so customers are not loyal to him as they have many vendors to choose from. However, he works very hard, from early morning to late evening, to keep his business doing well. He is using his loan of Kes 20,000 to buy more inventory that will meet his customer's demand. He hopes to be a wholesaler in the future. He describes himself as a hardworking man.

loans.use: Plastic basins and cups

loans.name: Jean

texts.en: Jean C. is from the town of Sto. Niño. She is 41 years old, married, and has four school-aged children. She makes a living by farming and hog-raising. She plants and harvests rice crops and grows pigs for fattening. She sells her harvest and pigs at the market. Jean is in need of additional capital for the farm and pigs. She applied for a loan of PHP 15,000 from CEVI so she could continue with her business. Jean is planning to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her farm and piggery.

loans.use: To fund the farm and piggery

loans.name: Jenelyn

texts.en:
Jenelyn C. is 48 years old and married. She supports her family by operating a cosmetics business.  She lives in Brgy. La Paz, Bogo, Cebu. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2008 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her cosmetics business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average income of PHP 10,000. Jenelyn is requesting a loan of  PHP 15,000 so that she could  purchase more cosmetics to sell.  This will be her sixth loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 8,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Jenelyn aspires to improve her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: To purchase more cosmetics to sell

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Adelaida

texts.en:
