Adelaida F. is  51 years old, married, and has two adult children and one child who attends high school.  She is a resident of GMA, Cavite City, Philippines. At this time, she is working hard to be able to send her youngest child to college, a dream for most Filipino parents like Adelaida as she herself is a high school graduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents could leave to their children.

Adelaida operates a tailoring business while overseeing operations of her ready-to-wear clothing business and a variety store. She mainly sells curtains, bedsheets, blankets, and other items for the home. Seasonal demands for clothing such as uniforms are available all year round. She also does repairs and alterations. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of PHP 2,500 every week from her tailoring business and variety store.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a loan for PHP 21,000. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities of raw materials such as fabric, thread, and newspapers for patterns. She also plans to use the loan to buy additional grocery items as replenishment for her variety store. She expects a boost in her income as she expands her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To buy more quantities of raw materials such as fabric, thread, and newspapers for patterns and assorted grocery items for her variety store

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan P. is from the town of Sto. Niño. She is 48 years old and married with five school-aged children. To make a living, Susan operates a business planting and harvesting rice for sale. She also fattens hogs for sale.

Susan joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI and is requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP to purchase fertilizer and feed. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support her family.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer and feed

loans.name: Stephen

texts.en: Stephen is a 35-year-old man, married to a peasant farmer and together they have two children aged 2 and 4 years. He operates a retail shop in Fort Portal, Uganda and has been in the business for five years now. He says that at the moment, there are no major challenges his business is facing and is only planning to see it grow into a wholesale business in the near future. However, Stephen says that he would like to diversify the sources of income he has currently so that his household income can increase. Thus, he is going to construct a house for rental purposes. Stephen intends to use the loan proceeds to buy land so that he can construct a house for rentals.

loans.use: To buy land to construct a house for rentals.

loans.name: Lita

texts.en:
This is Lita Mansojueto, 35, resident of GMA, Cavite City, Philippines. She is married to Amado, an overseas Filipino worker, and mother of two toddlers. She works hard so as to be able to educate both her children all the way through college. It is a dream for most Filipino parents like Lita as she is a high school graduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents could leave their children.

Lita operates a rug-making business. She mainly offers rugs, from round palm-sized ones, to the much larger doormats, braided quilts, and bed sheets. As rugs are a major part of Filipino housekeeping and cleaning, they are one of the most common products that can be bought — sometimes even from a peddler while you are riding in a speeding jeepney down the highway!  Lita earns a minimum of Php200 in sales every day.

To help her continue operating her business,  Lita is requesting a Php12,000 loan to buy more raw materials like fabric, thread and newspapers for patterns. She expects a boost in her income as she expands her business. She faithfully meets with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: buy more raw materials like fabric, thread

loans.name: Gene

texts.en:
Gene S. is 51-years old and married. She supports her family by farming. She lives in Sitio Canggapa, Brgy. Anahaw, Hinigaran, Negros Occidental. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2006 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard on her farm, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 7500. Gene is borrowing PHP 12000 so that she can continue to fund the operation of her rice field. This will be her ninth loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 12,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey  toward economic freedom. Gene aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way.	

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon — a title of esteem bestowed on a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Fund the operation of her rice field

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn L. is from the town of Sto. Niño. She is 54 years old and widowed with four children. To make a living, Evelyn raises rice for sale. She also spends raises pigs and runs a small sari-sari (variety) store.

Evelyn joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI and is requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizer and seeds. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer and seeds

loans.name: Liza

texts.en:
Liza C. is a married woman who lives in Brgy. Bliss, Bogo, Cebu. She earns her living buying and selling ready-to-wear clothing. Her husband, Danilo C., who is 40 years old, works as a company driver and also helps in his wife's business. They have four children between three and 19.  

Liza joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2008 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past four loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Liza has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 14,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 10,000, raising the family's standard of living. This time, for her fifth loan, she is borrowing PHP 14,000, which she intends to use to expand her clothing inventory so that she can continue to save up for the future education of her children. Liza C. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon — a title of esteem bestowed on a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Purchase more inventory

loans.name: Loreta

texts.en:
Loreta S., a married woman who lives in Sitio Sta. Cruz, Brgy. Don Virgilio, Medellin, Cebu, earns her living by operating a fishing business. Her husband, Jaime S., 51 years old, works as a fisherman to earn his living, and also helps in his wife's business activities. They have eight children who are between 9 and 29 years old.

Loreta joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2007 because she aspired to something better for her family. With the help of her past five loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Loreta has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 10,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 10,000, uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her sixth loan, she is borrowing PHP 10,000, which she intends to use to buy fishing gear so that she can continue to save up for future expansion of her business. Loreta S. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: To purchase fishing gear and equipment

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Ruby

texts.en:
This is Ruby V., 35, a resident of Caloocan City, Philippines. She is married to Ricardo V., a driver, and mother of their only child. At this time, she is working hard to be able to send her child all the way through college, a dream for most Filipino parents like Ruby as she herself is a highschool graduate and believes that a college diploma is the best legacy parents can leave to their children.

Ruby, who operates a rug-making business, offers rugs, from round palm-sized ones to much larger doormats, braided quilts and bed sheets, and other crafts that most rug-makers make every day. As rugs are a major part of Filipino housekeeping and cleaning, they are among the most common products that can be bought, sometimes even from a peddler while one is riding in a speeding jeepney down the highway. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of Php200 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php14,000 loan to buy more quantities of raw materials such as fabric, thread and newspapers for patterns. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.

Ruby dreams of being able to give her child a good and high quality education through all of her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week. * All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. Composed of 15 to 30 community partners, the groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To buy more quantities of raw materials such as fabric, thread and newspapers for patterns

loans.name: Umoja Virunga Group

texts.fr: Noella B. est  présidente du groupe Umoja Virunga, âgée de 28 ans, mariée, mère de 4 enfants, son mari est vendeur des habits usagers (friperie). Tous ses enfants étudient sauf le cadet. Juste l’après l’éruption du volcan Nyiragongo, qui aurait complètement détruit la ville de Goma en 2002, elle  commença son business  avec son fond propre par la vente des  habits usagers, en exerçant la même activité que son mari (friperie). Elle expose ses marchandises dans le marché central de Virunga. Ce nouveau crédit doit lui servir d’approvisionner  son stock avec un ballon d’habits (friperie), le reste lui servira de payer les frais scolaires de ses enfants et de se constituer l’épargne pour une marge de sécurité d’affaire. En plus, elle ambitionne devenir grossiste des habits usagers. La cliente Noella B. remercie Hekima pour  ses actions en faveur de pauvres exclus de banque classique.  Il sied de signaler que ce groupe Umoja Virunga est  composé de 18 femmes dont un homme  a représenté son épouse, qui fut empêchée lors de distribution de prêts.
texts.en: Noella B. is the president of the Umoja Virunga group. She is 28 years old, married, and has 4 children. Her husband is a second-hand clothing salesman. All of her children are students except for the youngest. Immediately after the eruption of the Nyiragongo volcano, which would go on to completely destroy the town of Goma in 2002, Noella started a business with her own funds selling used clothes, running the same type of business as her husband. She displays her goods at the central market in Virunga. This new loan should serve to supply her stock with one bale of (used) clothing, with the remainder being used to pay for her children's school expenses and to build up some savings for a safety net. Furthermore, she aspires to become a wholesale used clothing seller. Noella thanks Hekima (one of Kiva's field partners) for its work on behalf of the poor who are excluded from mainstream banking. It must be noted that the Umoja Virunga group is composed of 18 women, of whom one is represented by her husband, since she was unable to be there during the loan distribution.

loans.use: To buy used clothing

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Marilou

texts.en:
Marilou B. is a married woman who lives in Bliss, Brgy. Lapaz, Bogo, Cebu. She earns her living by operating a general store.  Her husband Eleazar B., who is 60 years old, is a retired employee who helps in his wife's business activities.  They have three children who are between 27 and 33 years old. Marilou joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2008 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past five loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Marilou has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 10,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 8,000, uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her sixth loan, she is borrowing PHP 10,000, which she intends to use to buy more stocks for the general store so that she could continue to save up for the future education of her children. Marilou B. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by joining the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org.

loans.use: To purchase more stock to sell

loans.name: Anita

texts.en:
This is Anita P., 57, a resident of Caloocan City, Philippines. She is married to Mateo P., a rice dealer, and mother to three young hard-working adults. By the grace of God, Anita has managed to support her children's schooling up to college level. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Anita operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a PHP 5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns by getting supplies at wholesale price and selling at piece rate.  Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of PHP 200 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 11,000 loan. She will be using the loan to buy more quantities of products like groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.
  
Anita dreams of being able to renovate her house soon, with all of her work with the business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To buy more products like groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en:
Lydia is a married woman with two children who attend school. She rents a house that has electricity but no piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For over eight years, she has been a telephone service operator and she operates a phone accessories shop selling to the market dwellers. Lydia faces a major challenge of price fluctuation of phone accessories in the market. She hopes to be self reliant in her business in the future. 

She decided to join Yehu to get a loan to boost her business. With the Kshs 40,000, she wants to purchase telephone credit cards and phone accessories.

loans.use: To purchase telephone credit cards and phone accessories.

loans.name: Nuru Group

texts.fr: Kavira D.  est  présidente du groupe Nuru, âgée de 31 ans, mariée, mère de 3 enfants, son mari est  tailleurs. Tous ses enfants étudient. Juste l’après l’éruption du volcan Nyiragongo, qui aurait complètement détruit la ville de Goma en 2002, elle  commença son business  avec son fond propre par la coupe couture, plus tard, elle bénéficia de crédit de l’IMF  Hekima de 50$. Elle installe son atelier au le marché central de Virunga. Ce nouveau crédit doit lui servir d’approvisionner  de tissus dames, tissus pour confection veste pour hommes. En plus, elle ambitionne déménager  et s’installe vers le centre ville pour plus de visibilité et gagner plus des marchés. La cliente Kavira D. remercie Hekima pour  ses actions en faveur de pauvres exclus de banque classique.  Il sied de signaler que ce groupe Nuru est  composé de 15 femmes.
texts.en: Kavira D. is the president of the Nuru group. She is 31 years old, married to a tailor, and has 3 children. All of her children are in school. Immediately after the eruption of the Nyiragongo volcano, which would go on to completely destroy the town of Goma in 2002, she started a business with her own funds making dresses. Later, she received a loan of $50 from the microfinance institution Hekima (one of Kiva's field partners). She has set up her workshop at the central market in Virunga. This new loan should serve to supply her with fabric for women's dresses and fabric to make men's jackets. Furthermore, she aspires to move and install herself near the centre of the town to increase her visibility and make more sales. Kavira D. thanks Hekima for its actions on behalf of the poor who are excluded from mainstream banking. It must be noted that the Nuru group is composed of 15 women.

loans.use: To buy fabric to make women's clothing and men's jackets

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Selonah

texts.en:
Selonah E. is a married woman who lives in Prk. Masinulondon, Tabao Proper, Valladolid, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating two business ventures:  a general store and crab fishing (Panggalan). Her husband Borlongan, who is 36 years old, works as a laborer to earn his living and helps in his wife's business activities.  They have three children who are between 4 to 8 years old. Selonah joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2004 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 10 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Selonah has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 19,500 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 8,000, uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her 11th loan, she is borrowing PHP 25,000, which she intends to use to buy more stock for general store and maintenance for crab traps so that she could continue to save up for the future education of her children. Selonah E. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by joining the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org.

loans.use: To purchase more stocks of goods to sell

loans.name: Auxilladora

texts.en:
Auxilladora I. is from the town of Sto. Niño. She is 59 years old. Auxilladora is widowed. She is a seamstress but focuses most of her time now farming and managing her sari-sari store. She cultivates her land to plant and harvest rice crops from it. She is hoping to have a better yield so she could earn more.

Auxilladora joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Auxilladora has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Auxilladora is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase seeds and fertilizers. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her business.

loans.use: To purchase seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Boniface

texts.en: Boniface A. O. is 28 years old and married. His wife stays in the house to take care of house chores while Boniface goes out every day to work at their business, which is located at a busy market called Khayega in Kakamega. Kakamega is the region in Kenya known for production of sugar cane and it's widely known as the sugar belt region. He makes and sells doughnuts and chapatis to the local people. He has been in this business for the last 10 years now. He says that this business is profitable and the major challenge he has is that there are many other people in the area doing the same kind of business as his, so customers are not loyal as they are spoilt for choice. He is also financially constrained. However, he works very hard from early morning to late evening to keep his business doing well. He is using his loan of Kes 20,000 to buy an oven to expand his business and be able to sell more to his customers. He hopes to open a mini-bakery in the future. He describes himself as determined, focused and self-motivated.

loans.use: To purchase an oven

loans.name: Teresa

texts.en:
This is Teresa M., 56, a resident of Caloocan City, Philippines. She is married to Ernesto M. and mother to a hard-working young adult. By the grace of God, Teresa has managed to support her child's schooling up to college level. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Teresa operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a PHP 5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns by getting supplies at wholesale price and selling at piece rate.  Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 200 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 13,000 loan. She will be using the loan to buy more quantities of products like groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.
  
Teresa dreams to be able to renovate her house soon, with all of her work with the business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To buy more products like groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory

loans.name: El's Group

texts.en: The two people shown in the photograph are low-income people who are jointly requesting a loan. They are all living in Kompong Chhnang Province in Cambodia. One of them, Mrs. El L., age 42, has been selected to be leader by the other member. To earn a living, she cultivates a rice crop in her own farmland. Mrs. El L.’s husband, Mr. Mear Mao, is a 46-year-old construction worker who makes about $3 per day. This couple has eight children. Four of the children are single and four are married and live in their own house. In addition, Mrs. El L. also sells fish paste, sugar, and rice to customers in the market. In order to earn extra profit and to make the business more successful, Mrs. El L. will be using the loan she requested to accumulate a larger quantity of her inventory items. The other borrower is Mr. Y.. He is a grocery seller who is asking for a loan to sustain her business growth.

loans.use: To accumulate a larger quantity of her inventory items.

loans.name: Ricardo

texts.en:
Ricardo D. is from the town of Sto. Niño. Ricardo is married and has six children. His younger children still go to school and he wants them to finish college and have bright futures. To make a living, Ricardo owns & operates a business raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. 

Ricardo joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ricardo has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Ricardo is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase farm inputs like seeds and fertilizers. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees for his children.

loans.use: To purchase farm inputs like seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Melania

texts.en:
57-year-old Melania dreams of giving the best to her children in their future. She and her husband hope to build a more accommodating and comfortable life for their family. She has two children: 32-year-old Emmil and 27-year-old Emmanuel. Both of the children graduated from college but are still dependent on her. To achieve this, she plans to develop her business. Melania has requested PHP 20,000 as additional capital for her junk shop business. This loan will be a great help for making their dreams come true and little by little, her business will grow to be a full shop soon. 

For 14 years as a member of ASHI, she has been trusted with loans that have improved their standard of living. Melania is also a good mother and is good at budgeting money for their daily expenditures, which are very expensive. She hopes that through her loans from ASHI partnership with KIVA; someday she will be able to save money for their future. Along with the business success she is dreaming about, she hopes to have their own passenger boat in the island of Talim, Binangonan in the province of Rizal. Her long-term goal is to give her family a better life, far away from the slave of poverty.

loans.use: To use as additional working capital for her junk shop business

loans.name: Miriam

texts.en:
Miriam is a married woman with four children, one of whom still attends school while others have graduated. She rents a house that has electricity and piped water, and her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

For over ten years, Miriam has operated her restaurant business, her customers being town dwellers and passersby. She faces the major challenge of competition from other restaurant operators and so hopes to expand and have a bigger restaurant in the future.

Miriam first joined Yehu to get a loan to start her business, and with the Kshs 70,000 loan she is now requesting, she will purchase a freezer, 10 bundles of maize flour, 5 sacks of beans and 10 sacks of sugar.

loans.use: To purchase a freezer, 10 bundles of maize flour, 5 sacks of beans and 10 sacks of sugar.

loans.name: Glyn

texts.en:
Glyn A. is a married woman who lives in Purok 2, Brgy. Alim, Hinobaan, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating three (3) business ventures:  a  Food Vending , an Avon dealership, MSE, FX and E-load Retailing and a fishing businesses. Her husband Ronald A., who is 35 years old, works as a Fisherman to earn his living and also helps in his wife's business activities.  They have one child who is 6 years old.

Glyn joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2007 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 6 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Glyn has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 11,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 5,000, uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her 7th loan, she is borrowing PHP 15,000, which she intends to use to fund her Food Vending and E-load Retailing business so that she could continue to save up for future education of her only child. Glyn A. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF:
 In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Fund the operations of  her food products business

loans.name: Khursheed's Group

texts.en:
Khursheed lives in a small city of Pakistan called Samundri. She has 48 years of age and married to M. S. who is a security guard. 
Khursheed performs her duties of a housewife and she also operates her animal sales business to supplement the income of her family. She has a set routine, getting up early in the morning, finishing the household chores and taking care of her animals. She specifically deals with goats because her clients are butchers and they demand goats to sell from their shops. She buys goats from the animal markets, raises them and sells them for a good profit.  

Khursheed is the mother of 6 sons. Her eldest son works in the factory. The next has a business selling clothes while 3rd one works in a poultry farm. The next two are enrolled in school and getting their education. The youngest of them are free and doesn't do anything. 

Khursheed has applied for a loan from Kiva partner, Asasah, for her animal sales business. With the loan, she will buy goats to raise and sell. She has been doing this business for many years and she is hopeful that this investment will bring good profits for her business. 

She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her 3rd loan application. She is a responsible client and responsibly paid her duties in previous loan years.  

Note: “In the photo, the lady who has holds a book (called Asasah Passbook) in her hands is Khursheed”.

loans.use: To buy goats to raise and sell

loans.name: Norma

texts.en:
Norma A. is a married woman who lives in Purok 2, Brgy. Alim, Hinobaan, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating two business ventures: a General Store and a fishing businesses. Her husband Felix A., who is 47 years old, works as a fisherman to earn his living and also helps in his wife's business activities.  They have three children who are between 16 to 24 years old. 

Norma joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1993 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 21 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Norma has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 15,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 10,000, uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her 22nd  loan, she is borrowing PHP 15,000, which she intends to use to buy stock for the general store so that she can continue to save up for future education of her children.

Norma A. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: 
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Purchase more stock to sell

loans.name: Nemia

texts.en:
Nemia M. is from the town of Sto. Niño. She is 37 years old. Nemia is married and has 4 children. Her eldest is 8 years old while the youngest is only 1. To make a living, Nemia owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. 

Nemia joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Nemia has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Nemia is requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP which will be used to purchase seeds, fertilizer and other farm supplies. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support her family financially.

loans.use: to purchase seeds, fertilizer and other farm supplies

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en:
Gloria S. is from the village of Cabisera 17-21. She is 39 years old. Gloria is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Gloria owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for fattening and sale. Gloria has been engaged in her business for over 7 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Gloria joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Gloria has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to to purchase young livestock to raise & sell in the future. Gloria is requesting a new loan of 6000 PHP which will be used to purchase young livestock to raise & sell. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Gloria from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase young livestock to raise & sell in the future

loans.name: Beth

texts.en: Beth is a 35-year-old lady, married and blessed with two children who are in school.  She sells groundnuts to earn a living.  She has engaged in the business for a period of seven years. She has managed to grow her business through Faulu Kenya.  She is advantaged because her business is located in a highly populated area and, therefore, she gets a good number of customers.  She has requested a loan of 50,000 Kes to buy groundnuts, a sufuria (cooking pot) and an umbrella. Since she does her business in the open air, she will use the umbrella to provide shade and the cooking pot for frying groundnuts.

loans.use: To buy groundnuts, a sufuria (cooking pot) and an umbrella.

loans.name: Berlita

texts.en:
Berlita A. is a married woman who lives in Purok Mauboy, Brgy. Nabulao, Sipalay City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating two (2) business ventures:  buying and selling peanuts and farming. Her husband Julieto A., who is 47 years old, works as a farmer to earn his living and helps in his wife's business activities.  They have five children who are between 4 and 25 years old. Berlita joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2006 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past seven loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Berlita has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 19,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 10,000, uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time for her eighth loan, she is borrowing PHP 20,000, which she intends to use to buy more peanuts to sell so that she can continue to save up for the future education of her children and home repairs. Berlita A. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by joining the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org.

loans.use: To fund the operations of buying and selling peanuts

loans.name: Rubina's Group

texts.en:
Rubina is a housewife. She stays at home and does her household responsibilities. She is very supportive in nature and is always ready to help her family at difficult times. She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband who is a private entrepreneur and sells fertilizers & seeds. He has a good clientele base to serve. He also operates a business selling milk & yogurt as a part-time business. He operates his milk shop in the market where he sells his products to many customers.  He will use the loan money to purchase fertilizer & seeds. He is sure that by having these items in bulk quantity he can increase his sales and supply to different other dealers in the market.  

Rubina has four sons and a daughter. Her first two sons are tailors by profession. The younger ones are getting their education from a local school. 
Rubina is hopeful that her husband will be able to bring positive changes to his business after making an investment in it. She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her second loan application. She is a responsible client and paid her duties responsibly in previous loan year.  

Note: “In the photo, the lady who has holds a book (called Asasah Passbook) in her hands is Rubina”.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer & seeds for selling

loans.name: Clara

texts.en:
Clara B. is 60 years old, married and supports her family by operating two business ventures:  buying and selling Banig-woven mats and a sugarcane plantation business. She lives in Brgy. Pinucotan, Toboso, Negros Occidental. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 1993 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her buying and selling woven mats and sugarcane businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 4,200. Clara is now borrowing PHP 15,000 so that she could continue to fund the operations of her sugarcane plantation.  This will be her 21st loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 20,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Clara aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the Dungganon way. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by joining the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org.

loans.use: To fund the operations of her Banig and Sugarcane plantation

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
Erlinda B. is from the town of Sto. Niño. She is married. To make a living, Erlinda owns & operates a business planting and harvesting rice for sale. Erlinda wants to improve her income so she works hard to achieve it.

Erlinda joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Erlinda has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Erlinda is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizer and seeds. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer and seeds

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn B. is married, 29-years old, and supports her family by operating three business ventures. These businesses are crystal installing, pig fattening, and farming. She lives in Prk. Mabinuligon, Brgy. Maricalum, Sipalay City, Negros Occidental. She has been a member of the NWTF - Project Dungganon since 2007, and she has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans and hard work. As a result, she is helping her family to become more economically stable, and she now earns an average monthly income of PHP 15,000. 

Jocelyn is borrowing PHP 18,000 so that she can continue to purchase raw materials. This will be her 7th loan from NWTF - Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 15,000 was repaid well within its term, and was a step in her journey toward economic freedom. Jocelyn aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future by following the Dungganon way. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Purchase raw materials

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Sakina's Group

texts.en:
Sakina lives in Samundri, a small city known for its agriculture industry, located in Punjab. A housewife who stays at home and performs her household duties, she is very cooperative and always ready to help her family to overcome life's difficulties.

Sakina is married to M. S., who works in the field growing a variety of seasonal crops to fulfill the basic needs of the family. He has vast experience and knowledge in this livelihood. They have two sons, one who works on a poultry farm and also sells goats, while the younger one works in a factory on a monthly wage.

A regular client of Kiva partner Asasah, Sakina is requesting her second loan so her elder son can buy goats to sell to his customers at a good profit. She is confident that this investment will be a productive one for her son and that his business will be improved. Sakina is a responsible client and paid her duties responsibly in her previous loan year.

Note: In the photo, the lady holding a book (called Asasah Passbook) in her hands is Sakina.

loans.use: To buy goats for selling

loans.name: Thomas

texts.en: Thomas is a member of Faulu Kenya under Dagoretti Pamoja group.  He joined the group as a businessman who sells secondhand clothes.  He also is a farmer.  Thomas gets a good number of customers because his business is located in the market.  He hopes to someday open a boutique.  He has requested a loan of 20,000 Kes to buy clothes, especially T-shirts, sweaters, and track suits.

loans.use: To buy clothes, especially T-shirts, sweaters and track suits

loans.name: Pamela's Group

texts.en:
Pamela C. is from the village of Union, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is 32 years old. Pamela is the group leader for a six-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Pamela is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Pamela runs a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling food and daily use products in the local community. Pamela has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 4,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month.

In 2006, Pamela joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Pamela has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and to provide working capital. Pamela is requesting a new loan of 9,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be Pamela's second loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Kenneth

texts.en: Kenneth Zaddock M. is forty-two years old and is married to a teacher. They have four children aged between twelve and six years old and they hope to give their children a good education through the university level. His business is located in Kakamega. Kakamega is the region in Kenya known for production of sugar cane. It is widely known as the "sugar belt region." He has a motorcycle, which he uses for transport to serve the local people. Besides this business, Kenneth owns a retail shop in which he sells general items. He has been in this business for the last eight years. He says that this business is profitable and his major challenge is that there are many other people in the area doing the same kind of business he is doing, so customers are not loyal, as they have plenty of choices. However, he works very hard from early morning to late evening to keep his business doing well. He is using his loan of 80,000 Kenyan shillings to buy stock of soft drinks to boost his business. He hopes to be a wholesaler in the future. He describes himself as hardworking and visionary.

loans.use: To buy soft drinks as stock for his general store

loans.name: Ahmadchon

texts.ru: Эркаев Ахмадчон проживает в городе Турсунзаде. Возраст, 34 года. Женат, имеет 3 детей. Образование среднее. Работает на рынке "Дехкон". Занимается продажей овощей и приправ. В этой области более 4 лет. Кредит берет для увеличения товарооборота.
texts.en: Ahmadchon E. lives in the city of Tursun-zoda.  He is 34 years old, married and has 3 children.  He has a secondary education and works at the "Dehkon" market.  Ahmadchon is involved in sales of vegetables and spices.  He has been in this business for over 4 years.  He is requesting this loan in order to increase product turnover.

loans.use: Increasing product turnover

loans.name: Rosemarie

texts.en:
Rosemarie C. is a single woman who lives in Purok Kalobihan, Barangay Cartagena, Sipalay City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating three business ventures: buying and selling rice, a general store, and farming businesses. Rosemarie joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2008 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past four loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Rosemarie has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of 9,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 8,000, uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her fifth loan, she is borrowing PHP 15,000, which she intends to use to buy rice to resell so that she can continue to save up for future expansion of her business. Rosemarie C. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 


About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means "honorable"). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed upon a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Purchase more rice to sell

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Keng

texts.en:
Keng B., age 64, has been living in the province of Kompong Tom, which is the best territory for farming. Keng B. owns a big farm that she inherited from her grandmother. Keng B. is now married and has nice children. Her husband (pictured here) works in the farm fields frequently alongside her. 

Keng B. currently plants a peanut crop and she estimates that she will harvest it within the next two months when the plants mature. Keng B. will use the income from selling her mature produce to better meet her family’s needs during the financial crisis. 

Keng B. said that she always rented the neighbor’s cow in order to alleviate the chore of plowing the farmland. Currently, she hopes to buy her own cow and that is why she is applying for a loan from Kiva. Keng B. was not available the day of the photo, so her husband is in the photo instead.

loans.use: To buy her own cow

loans.name: Hazel

texts.en: Hazel L. is a married woman who lives in Prk. Hangkayaw, Brgy. Nabulao, Sipalay City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating three business ventures: a general store, a rice mill and farming. Her husband, Alipio Loquiso, who is 47 years old, works as a rice mill operator to earn his living and also helps in his wife's business activities. They have four children who are between 5 and 21 years old. Hazel joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1998 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 14 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Hazel has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of 10,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 13,000, uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her 15th loan, she is borrowing PHP 12,000, which she intends to use to buy fertilizers for her farm so that she can continue to save up for the future education of her children and the improvement of her businesses. Hazel L. is a Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable) woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon . Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Purchase more stock to sell

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Ma. Jesusa

texts.en: A loving mother and member of Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc. (ASHI), a Kiva microfinance partner in the Philippines, Ma. Jesusa is grateful for access to capital and other services such as savings and insurance. With the support of ASHI and Kiva lenders, she is hopeful that her business endeavor will provide steady income and improvements in her family’s quality of life to move out of poverty level. Ma. Jesusa is a very busy entrepreneur managing a resale business. Her previous loan from Kiva provided working capital to expand her business and purchase additional inventory for her ventures. With the loan, Ma. Jesusa has witnessed that her income has almost doubled since she has attracted new customers with additional inventory. For this reason, she is requesting another Kiva loans to continue to support her resale business. She will resell the goods in their village. People will just come to her store and will buy what they need. This will allow her to grow her business further so that their children fulfill their dreams of achieving college degrees. Ma. Jesusa joined Kiva partner ASHI in 2008, attracted by ASHI's lower interest rates and range of loans for business, education and house repair. Prior to ASHI, Ma. Jesusa had no access to capital to support her entrepreneurial endeavor. Positive growth from her business has helped Ma. Jesusa fund the education of her children. Since joining ASHI, Ma. Jesusa has experienced positive changes in her life as she now built her own home. She hopes her business will continue to flourish so she can provide long-term financial stability for her family and experience a life that’s full of happiness.

loans.use: Will continue to support her resale business

loans.name: Virginia

texts.en:
Virginia S. is 64 years old, married, and supports her family by operating one business venture: a Carinderia (or food stall). She lives in Bogy City, La Paz, Bogo, Cebu.

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2008 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her Carinderia (food stall), she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 5,000.

Virginia is now borrowing PHP 10000 so that she can continue to fund her business. This will be her 6th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 8,000, which she paid off well within its term was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Virginia aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way.

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Fund the operations of her Carinderia (food stall)

loans.name: Philomene

texts.en:
Philomene is 60 years old. She is married and has five children between the ages of 9 and 30. Her youngest child goes to school. Her husband has no job. Philomene sells clothes for ladies. 

With this loan, she will buy more clothes to sell. She will increase the volume of her clothing sales and hopefully generate more profit from her business. She says that her business is successful because of customer satisfaction. In the future, she would like to own a large shop filled with ladies' clothes where many ladies can buy from her.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to sell

loans.name: Catherine

texts.en:
Catherine is 26 years old and a single mother of one. She runs a boutique to earn a living.  She has been in the business for four years.  She appreciates Faulu Kenya for giving her financial support; hence, she has been able to add business stock. She hopes to open another boutique in the future.  

She has requested a loan of 45,000 Kenyan shillings to buy more clothes so as to keep stock for the Christmas festive season, when the demand is high.

loans.use: To buy more clothes

loans.name: Abudalahim

texts.en:
Abudalahim is 55 years old. He is married and has four children between the ages of 14 and 20. Two of his children go to school. Abudalahim is a tailor and his wife works as a knitter. He has had this business for 30 years. 

With this loan, he will buy more fabric to make various items of clothing, which he will sell. With the profit, he will renovate his house. He says that his business is successful because he knows how to tailor ladies' dresses well. In the future, he would like to export his tailored clothes to neighboring countries.

loans.use: To buy more fabric to make clothing

loans.name: Solina

texts.en:
Solina is 23 years is old. She is married and has 3 children between the ages of one and fourteen. One of her children goes to school. Her husband works as a driver. Solina sells milk, tea and juices. She has had this business for one year. 

With this loan she will buy more milk and tea to sell. With the profit she will purchase more drink items to increase her total sales. She says that her business is successful because she offers good customer care. In the future she would like to own a mini supermarket.

loans.use: To buy more milk and juice to sell

loans.name: Ali

texts.en:
Ali is a married man with a son who attends school. He owns a house that  has neither electricity nor piped water. His greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

He operates a blacksmith business making the Kenya ceramic "jiko". This is a portable stove that uses charcoal as fuel. Therefore the challenge lies in improving the stoves that he makes and the lack of enough raw materials. Ali hopes to open a big workshop of blacksmith in the future.

With the Kshs 15,000 he wants to purchase used containers to make jiko's (charcoal burning braziers). He decided to join Yehu to get financial assistance and education on how to plan his future business.

loans.use: To purchase used containers to make jiko's (charcoal burning braziers)

loans.name: Flordeliza

texts.en:
Flordeliza P. is a widow who lives in Purok 2, Brgy. 2, Hinobaan, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating a business venture: a tailoring business.  Flordeliza joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2000 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 20 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Flordeliza has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 15,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 6,000,  uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her 21st loan, she is borrowing PHP 20,000, which she intends to use to buy threads for sewing machine so that she could continue to save up for future to have a new sewing machine and improvement of business. 

Flordeliza P. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: 
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Purchase supplies for a sewing machine

loans.name: Sudi

texts.en: Sudi is 28 years old. He is married and has one child who is one year old. Sudi sells juice, milk and soda. He has spent one and half years in this business. With this loan he will buy more juice and soda to sell. With the profit he will increase the volume of soda and juice he has been selling. He says that his business will prosper because of his good services and quality products. He would like to sell clothes in the future.

loans.use: To buy more juice and soda to sell.

loans.name: Emelita's Group

texts.en:
Emelita B. is from the village of San Luis, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is 42 years old. Emelita is the group leader of a 7-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Emelita is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Emelita owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Emelita has been engaged in her business for over 22 years and earns approximately 3500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Emelita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Emelita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. Emelita is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 7th loan taken out by Emelita from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Jeannette

texts.en: Jeannette is 23 years old. She is married and has two children between the ages of one and five. she also cares her sister who is seventeen years old. None of her children goes to school. Her husband works as a technician. Jeannette is a photographer. She has spent 2 years in this business. With this loan, she will buy more cameras in order to take a greater variety of photos. With the profit from the business, she will renovate her house. She says that her business is successful because she makes quality photos. In the future, she would like to have her own photo studio.

loans.use: To buy more cameras in order to take photos

loans.name: Faustin

texts.en: Faustin is 47 years old. He is married and has 10 children between the ages of 1 and 23. Nine of his children are students and are currently enrolled in school. Faustin sells different types of crafts in his shop. His wife helps him with his work. He has had this business for four years. With the loan, he will buy more crafts to sell. With the profit, he will pay school fees for his children. He says that his business is successful because he knows all the people near him and they appreciate his business. In the future, he would like to sell in a big market like that one in an urban area where there are more people than his local area.

loans.use: To buy more crafts to sell

loans.name: Bertta

texts.en: Bertta is a 28-year-old married lady. For a living, she sells groundnuts. She has been running the business for four years. Her husband, who is also a businessman, supports her financially. She has seen her lifestyle changing through Faulu Kenya. This is because she has managed to move to a better house. She sees herself transforming her business into wholesale in the future. She has requested a loan of 15,000 Kenyan shillings to buy groundnuts.

loans.use: To buy groundnuts

loans.name: Alma

texts.en:
Alma S. is a married woman who lives in Purok Daisy, Brgy. Talacagay, Hinobaan, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating two business ventures:  food vending and farming. Her husband Milo S., who is 51 years old, works as a farmer to earn his living and helps in his wife's business activities.  They have two children who are 18 and 22 years old, respectively. Alma joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1998 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 14 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Alma has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 7,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 4,300, uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her 15th loan, she is borrowing PHP 10,000, which she intends to use to buy fertilizers and glutinous rice for her food vending so that she can continue to save or the future education of her child. Alma S. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by joining the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer and glutinous rice

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en: Margaret M. L. is fifty-nine years old and is married to a farmer. They have three children aged between eighteen and twenty-eight years old. Her business is located at a busy market in Kakamega. Kakamega is the region in Kenya known for production of sugar cane and it is widely known as the "sugar belt" region. She has a shop in which she sells groceries and other general items to the local people. Besides this business, Margaret also does farming. She has been in this business for the last five years. She says that this business is profitable and her major challenge is that there are many other people in the area doing the same kind of business as hers, so customers are not loyal, as they have plenty of choices. However, she works very hard from early morning to late evening to keep her business doing well. She is using her loan of 40,000 Kenyan shillings to stock her grocery store in order to grow her business while meeting her customers' needs. She hopes to be a wholesaler in the future and she sees herself owning a plot. She describes herself as a hardworking and visionary woman.

loans.use: To buy cabbages, onions, potatoes and tomatoes

loans.name: Sao

texts.en: Sao H. is a rattan cupboard and bed seller who is 41 and is a married mother caring for six children, all of whom are no longer in school. Since 2006, Sao H. and her husband have owned a small rattan cupboard and bed sales point. This couple also orders rattan items in bulk from braiders and takes them to retail door-to-door across the province. They always take a week or two weeks to sell their products. Sao H. is now running her business very well because she sells her items at a reasonable price. In order to better satisfy the needs of the customers, Sao H. seeks a loan to stock a bigger amount of rattan beds to sell.

loans.use: To stock a bigger amount of rattan beds to sell.

loans.name: Agbuidohoin

texts.fr: A. Agbuidohoin est née vers 1975 à Comé au Bénin et est mariée à PADONOU Dieudonné. Le couple a quatre enfants, tous scolarisés qui sont à leur charge. Il y a près de treize ans que la famille s’est installée à Sègbèya, un quartier de Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Agbuidohoin vient en aide à son mari et supporte avec lui les dépenses de la famille. Pour faire face à ses besoins, Agbuidohoin mène comme activité la vente de divers produits (pâtes alimentaires, sucre, conserves de tomate et de sardine, mayonnaise, savons, plateaux d’œufs frais, des condiments de sauce, des céréales, du lait) et également des poissons fumés à son domicile et à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Agbuidohoin s’approvisionne dans le même marché et exerce cette activité depuis une dizaine d’année. C’est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, qui a  remboursé son dernier crédit avec une légère difficulté, par suite d’une mévente. Aujourd'hui encore, Agbuidohoin sollicite un cinquième prêt pour rehausser le niveau de son activité et mieux satisfaire sa clientèle.
texts.en: Agbuidohoin A. was born around 1975 in Comé, Benin, and is married to Dieudonné Padanou. The couple have four children, all of whom are in their care and attend school. For close to thirteen years, the family has lived in Sègbèya, a district of Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Agbuidohoin helps her husband in providing for the family. To meet her needs, Agbuidohoin runs a business selling various items (pasta, sugar, canned tomatoes and sardines, mayonnaise, soap, trays of fresh eggs, sauce condiments, cereal, milk, etc.) as well as smoked fish, at her home and at Dantokpa, the international market in Benin. Agbuidohoin gets her supplies at the same market and has run this business for about ten years. She is a longstanding client of ALIDÉ (one of Kiva's field partners), and repaid her previous loan with a slight degree of difficulty due to a sales slump. Currently, Agbuidohoin is seeking her fifth loan to raise the level of her business and better satisfy her clientele.

loans.use: To buy various items (pasta, canned goods, soap, cereals, fresh tomatoes, onions, peppers, fish, etc.)

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to expand his small shop by buying more items to sell to his customers

loans.name: Florence

texts.en: Florence J. lives in Kyebando neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is married and has four children, all of whom are in school.   She also takes care of additional family members (sisters). Florence's business is a beauty salon.  She has been in this business for over 10 years and works 7 days out of every week.  Florence works from home, by means of retail. Florence has requested a loan of 400,000/- Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy boxes of hair relaxers and braids. The main business challenge for Florence is seasonality.  Her goals and aspirations for her business are to own a bridal salon.  Florence lives in a home that she owns with access to electricity and piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include school fees and feeding the family.

loans.use: To buy more boxes of hair realxers and braids

loans.name: Hellen

texts.en: Hellen L. is currently in the business of selling tomatoes at the market and is requesting a loan to purchase more tomatoes to sell.  Hellen is 37 years old and is married with a husband who is a policeman. She has three children who are in school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a shop.

loans.use: To purchase more tomatoes to sell

loans.name: Elijah

texts.en: Elijah is 30 years old, married and blessed with two children.  For two years, he has been earning a living by repairing bicycles and selling bicycle spare parts.  He was previously working on contract before he went into business.  He hopes to open another outlet of his business in the future.  He appreciates Faulu Kenya for supporting him financially because he has managed to add to his business inventory.  With the loan of 40,000 Kenyan shillings, he will buy bicycle spare parts such as peddles, frames, forks, tubes and tires.

loans.use: To buy bicycle spare parts such as peddles, frames, forks, tubes and tires.

loans.name: Armie

texts.en:
Armie S. is from the town of Sto. Niño. She is 40 years old. Armie is married. To make a living, Armie owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale.

Armie joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Armie has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Armie is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase farm inputs and hog feeds. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support the immediate members of her family.

loans.use: To purchase farm inputs and hog feeds

loans.name: Annet

texts.en: Annet L. lives in the Kyebando neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is married and has three children, two of whom are in school.  Annet has a bar business.  She has been in this business for eight years and she works seven days a week.  Annet runs her business from home, by means of retail.  Annet has requested for a loan of 400,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more crates of beer and soda.  She also generates additional income through poultry farming. The main business challenge for Annet is the rainy season beacuse it hinders her customers to reach out to her and also defaulters .  Her goals and aspirations for her business is to own fully stocked bar.  Annet lives in a home that she owns; she has access to electricity but doesn't have access to piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include school fees and feeding her family.

loans.use: To buy more crates of beer and soda

loans.name: Merilin

texts.en: Merilin A. is currently in the business of selling clothes at home and is requesting a loan to purchase more clothes to sell.
