Merilin is 24 years old and is married with a husband who is a clerk in the Assembly.  She has two children who are not in school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes to sell

loans.name: Florah

texts.en: Florah M. is a married lady with two children, ages six and two and one-half years old. Her business is located at Shinyalu market in Kakamega. Kakamega is a region in Kenya widely known as the "sugar belt" for its production of sugar cane. Florah has a shop in which she sells general items to the local people. In addition to this business, Florah also has a motorcycle that she uses to provide transportation services. She has been in this business for the past three years. She says that her business is profitable and that her major challenge is financial constraints. However, she works very hard from early morning to late evening to keep her business doing well. She is using her loan of 30,000 KES to stock general items in her store in order to meet her customers' needs and grow her business. She will also use part of the money to repair her motorcycle. She hopes to grow her business and move to another location that will enable her to attract more customers. She also hopes to give her children a quality education up to the university level. She describes herself as polite, honest, and hardworking.

loans.use: To purchase inventory for general store and motorcycle parts

loans.name: Pardahol

texts.ru: Умарова Пардахол проживает в городе Турсунзаде. Возраст, 40 лет. Не замужем. Образование среднее. Более 4 лет занимается торговлей на рынке. Арендует торговую точку, где продает курагу и фисташки. Этот бизнес приносит доход. Кредит берет для увеличения товарооборота. Она хочет расширить свою деятельность.
texts.en: Pardahol U. lives in the city of Tursun-zoda.  She is 40 years old, single.  She has a secondary education and has been involved in retail sales at a market for over 4 years.  Pardahol leases a retail stall, where she sells dried apricots and pistachios.  This business yields a profit.  Pardahol is requesting this loan in order to increase product turnover.  She wants to expand her business.

loans.use: Increasing product turnover

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary O. is a farmer from the town of Kisii in western Kenya. She is 38 years old, widowed, and has one two-year-old child.  Mary has been farming for 10 years and employs one farmhand. Her mixed farm produces milk, beans, maize, and bananas, which she sells at the local market. She depends on the income from her farming activities to provide for the basic needs of her family.  

She has requested a loan of 35,000 KES through Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. She says that her family will be guaranteed enough milk for consumption and her income will increase through the sale of milk. She will, therefore, be able to provide for her needs and that of her baby.

Her primary challenges have been lack of market for her products, high cost of quality-bred cows, and lack of artificial insemination services in her area. She hopes to expand her farming in the future and venture into poultry farming as well.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en: Joyce K. is 30 years old, widowed, and has one child who attends school.  She is currently in the business of selling tomatoes at the market and is requesting a loan to stock fish, onions, and cooking oil to sell.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a shop.

loans.use: To stock fish, onions, and cooking oil to sell

loans.name: Andrew

texts.en: Andrew is 37 years-old and married with three children.  To earn a living, he hires construction equipment. He was previously employed in an insurance firm as an insurance agent before he went into business.  As a member of Kiva partner Faulu Kenya, he has been able to invest more in his business.  He hopes that he will own a big construction firm in the future.  He has requested for 20,000 Kes to buy a puller machine for hire.

loans.use: To buy a puller machine for hire.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy a sewing machine and other items needed for a tailoring business

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en: Joseph M.  is currently in the business of selling various items at a shop and is requesting a loan to stock more items such as bags of sugar, cartons of salt, etc. to sell.  Joseph is 40 years-old and is married with a husband that is an engineer. She has five children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a restaurant.

loans.use: To stock items such bags of sugar, cartons of salt, etc to sell

loans.name: Simon

texts.en:
Simon M. is 46 years-old and married with four children aged between 10 and 15 years-old. His business is located at Sejeri market in Kakamega. Kakamega is the region in Kenya known for production of sugar cane and widely known as the sugar belt region. He has a shop in which he sells general items to the local people. Besides this business, Simon mills timber and farms. He has been in this business for the last three years now. He says that this business is profitable and the major challenge he has is financial constraints. 

Simon works very hard from early morning to late evening to keep his business doing well. He is using his loan of Kes 20,000 to stock general items to grow his business while meeting his customer needs. He hopes to grow his business and have a big timber yard in the future. He also hopes to give his children quality education to the university level. He describes himself as polite, honest and focussed.

loans.use: To purchase rice, sugar, detergents, etc.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary B. lives in the Kamwokya ButakaB. neighborhood of the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is married and has eight children, four of whom are in school.  Mary has a business of selling charcoal.  She has been in this business for seven years, and she works seven days out of every week. Mary sells her products at the market by means of retail.

Mary has requested for a loan of 600,000/- Ugandan Shillings from Kiva partner MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more sacks of charcoal.  The rainy season is one of the main business challenges for Mary. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to start going to villages for charcoal.  Mary lives in a home that she owns but she doesn't have access to electricity or piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include school fees and feeding the family.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal.

loans.name: Francisca

texts.en:
Helena Musyoka is 35 years-old and married with six children aged between five and 14 years-old.  They hope to give quality education to the university level to their children. Her business is located at the busy Mwingi market though she is served by the Thika branch office. Thika is the region in Kenya known for the production of pineapples. 

Helena sells rope to the local people and has been in this business for six years now. She says that this business is profitable and the major challenge she has is transport since she walks from one area to another to sell the ropes. However, she works very hard to keep her business doing well. She is using her loan of Kes 15,000 to buy more rope to increase her business. She hopes to be selling ropes in bulk in future. She describes herself as aggressive, committed and innovative.

loans.use: To buy rope to sell.

loans.name: Flora

texts.en: Flora M.  is 33 years old, married, and has six children, four of whom attend school.  Her husband is a farmer.  Flora is currently in the business of selling green vegetables such as dodo, okra, tomatoes, etc. She is requesting a loan to stock fish to sell.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay the school fees for her children.

loans.use: To stock fish to sell

loans.name: Gorret

texts.en: Gorret N. lives in the Kyebando neighborhood in Kampala, Uganda.  She is married and has three children who attend school.   Gorret is a poultry farmer.  She has been in this business for two years, and she works seven days a week. Gorret has requested for a loan of 400,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy bags of  poultry feed.   The main business challenges for Gorret include thieves and seasonality.  Her goals and aspirations for her business are to own 2000 chickens.  Gorret owns her home; she doesn't have access to electricity and piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include school fees.

loans.use: To buy chicken feed

loans.name: 020304-Bac Son-Hoang Phu Group

texts.en:
Thu M. T. is a 39 year-old female living in the town of Hoang Hoa.  Thu is the group leader of a six-member group loan offered by Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.  The official name of this borrowing group is 020304-Bac Son-Hoang Phu.

Thu is married and has two school-aged children.  To making a living, Thu operates a family member's fishing business.  While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from harvesting and selling wild-caught fish in the local community.  Thu has been engaged in this business for over 19 years and earns approximately 2,000,000 VND a month.

In 2008, Thu joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Thu has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,079,800 VND from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  This previous loan was used to purchase additional fish to sell.  She is now requesting a new loan of 6,000,000 VND, which will be used to repair a transport vehicle used in the business.  The loan will be the third loan taken out by Thu from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  Thu plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand the business.

About the Other Borrowers in the Group:

1. Hoa T. M. is a 43 year-old female who is requesting a 6,000,000 VND loan to support her business in the retail sector selling home products.

2. Nga N. T. is a 29 year-old female who is requesting a 6,000,000 VND loan to support her business in the food sector making and selling food.


3. Thuy T. T. is a 38 year-old female who is requesting a 6,000,000 VND loan to support her business in the food sector making and selling food.

4. Nhi N. T. is a 38 year-old female who is requesting a 6,000,000 VND loan to support her business in the food sector making and selling food.

5. Thuy P. T. is a 32 year-old female who is requesting a 6,000,000 VND loan to support her business in the food sector making and selling food.


About Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

The mission of Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainable financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in the Thanh Hoa province.


*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To repair a transport vehicle used in the business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Ma. Edelita

texts.en:
Ma. Edelita F. would like to expand her sari-sari (variety) store and is requesting a Kiva loan of 20,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) in order to purchase additional groceries for her store. She believes that having more items will help her retain her current customers as well as attract new clients in the neighborhood.

Ma. Edelita reported that her previous loan helped her maintain the growth of her business. Moreover, the income she gets from the business is very helpful in sustaining her family needs. She was able to see her oldest child graduate with a mechanical engineering degree and be currently employed with a private company. She also hopes to see her other two children complete college.

A proud member of Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc. (ASHI), a Kiva microfinance partner in the Philippines, since 2008, Ma. Edelita has been a dedicated member, regularly attending weekly center meetings. She has a solid record in repayments on her previous loans. Her long-term goals are to have a profitable business and to invest in her home. Additionally, she hopes to continue her business as a sustainable livelihood to support her family.

loans.use: To purchase additional groceries for her store

loans.name: Viocies

texts.en: Viocies J. is currently in the business of selling beer and soda at the market, and is requesting a loan to stock more crates of these goods to sell. She is 37 years old and married to a husband who is a business man. She has five children and only two of her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build up a bar.

loans.use: To stock more crates of beer and soda to sell

loans.name: Zarbibi

texts.ru: Махмудова Зарбиби жительница города Турсунзаде. Возраст, 53 года. Замужем, имеет 6 детей. Муж работает на рынке поваром. Сама Зарбиби имеет среднее образование. Арендует торговую точку на рынке, где продает обувь. Этим видом деятельности занимается уже 8 лет. Кредит берет для увеличения ассортимента товара.
texts.en: Zarbibi M. lives in the city of Tursun-zoda.  She is 53 years old, married and has 6 children.  Her husband works as a cook at a market.  Zarbibi has a secondary education.  She leases a retail outlet at a market, where she sells shoes.  She has been involved in this business for 8 years.  She is requesting this loan in order to expand the merchandise assortment.

loans.use: Expanding goods assortment

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy additional inventory for a small store

loans.name: Aisha

texts.en:
Aisha K. lives in the Katanga Wandegeya neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is single and has three children, two of whom are in school. She also takes care of additional family members (a sister and a brother). Aisha has a call box business and sells air time. She has been in this business for six years, and works seven days a week. Aisha sells her products from home, but at times goes door-to-door. Aisha has requested a loan of 300,000 Ugandan shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more air time. She also generates additional income working with an HIV/AIDS prevention team called (CAB).

The main business challenge(s) for Aisha include the rainy season. Her goals and aspirations for her business is to own a fully set-up call center. Aisha lives in a home that she rents; she has no access to electricity or piped water. Her major monthly expenses include rent and school fees.

loans.use: To buy more air time

loans.name: Betty

texts.en: Betty K. is currently in the business of selling cold drinks and snacks such as soda and ice cream, and is requesting a loan to stock more crates of soda to sell. Betty is 25 years old and married. Her husband is a logistic officer. She has five children, who all go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house.

loans.use: To stock more crates of soda to sell

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en: Rebecca N. lives in the Lubya neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is single and has two children, both of whom are in school. She also takes care of an additional family member (her sister's daughter). Rebecca is in the business of selling charcoal. She has been in this business for over four years and works seven days a week. Rebecca sells her products at the market for retail. Rebecca has requested a loan of 300,000 Ugandan shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bags of charcoal. The main business challenge(s) for Rebecca include seasonality. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to start going to villages for charcoal and plan for her future. Rebecca owns the home she lives in; she has access to electricity but doesn't have access to piped water. Her major monthly expenses include school fees.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal

loans.name: Uguloy

texts.ru: Махмудова Угулой проживает в городе Турсунзаде. Возраст, 20 лет. Замужем, детей не имеет. Муж на заработках в Росси. Сама Угулой имеет среднее образования. Работает на рынке "Дехкон". Она готовит и продает, блещи, пирожки и печенья. Этим видом деятельности занимается уже 3 года. Кредит берет для увеличения товарооборота.
texts.en: Uguloy M. lives in the city of Tursun-zoda.  She is 20 years old, married and has no children.  Her husband works in Russia.  Uguloy has a secondary education.  She works at the "Dehkon" market.  She prepares and sells pies, piroshki and cookies.  She has been in this business for 3 years.  Uguloy is requesting this loan in order to increase product turnover.

loans.use: Increasing product turnover

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Rosa

texts.en:
Rosa M. is from the village of Amoyong, Wao, Lanao del Sur. She is 30 years old. Rosa is married and has two infant-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, toothpaste, canned goods and junk foods in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately $250 a month for these activities.

In 2010, Rosa joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell and as working capital. 

Rosa is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which again will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be her 2nd loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated improve her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and as working capital

loans.name: Doruka

texts.en: Doruka O. is currently in the business of selling tomatoes at home and is requesting a loan to stock more tomatoes to sell.  Doruka is 35 years old and is married to a businessman. She has five children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house.

loans.use: Stock more tomatoes to sell

loans.name: Jean

texts.en:
Jean L. is from the village of Amoyong, Wao, Lanao del Sur. She is 30 years old. Jean is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, toothpaste, canned goods and snack foods in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately $125 a month for these activities.

In 2009, Jean joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. 

Jean is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be her 3rd loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and as working capital

loans.name: Nouratou

texts.fr: B. Nouratou est née le 24 Mars 1975 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Nouratou est mariée à ADEKAMBI Sundé, un commerçant. Le couple a trois enfants, tous scolarisés et à leur charge. Nouratou vit depuis dix huit ans au quartier Agbodjèdo à Cotonou, avec  sa famille. Le couple subvient ensemble aux besoins de la famille. Nouratou a très tôt abandonné l’école, puis a appris la coiffure. Parallèlement à cette activité qu’elle mène, Nouratou vend également des mèches et divers produits cosmétiques dans sa boutique size à Midombo. Nouratou achète ses produits à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. C’est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé ayant déjà bénéficié de cinq crédits qui ont tous été bien remboursés. Face à la demande de plus en plus nombreuse de sa clientèle, Nouratou sollicite un autre crédit en vue d’augmenter son stock de produits et d’accroître son chiffre d’affaire.
texts.en:
B. Nouratou was born on March 24, 1975 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin.  She is married to ADEKAMBI Sundé, a merchant.  The couple have three children, who are all in school and in their care.  Nouratou has been living for eighteen years in the Agbodjèdo district in Cotonou with her family.  The couple jointly provide for their family.

Early on, Nouratou dropped out of school and then learned how to style hair.  Concurrent to this business that she operates, she sells hair extensions and various cosmetic products in her shop located in Midombo.  She gets her supplies at Dantokpa, the international market of Benin. 

She is a previous client of ALIDé having already had five loans, which have all been repaid.  Facing the burgeoning demand from her customer base, Nouratou is requesting another loan with the aim of increasing her stock of goods and her sales.

loans.use: Buying hair extensions and cosmetics

loans.name: Annet

texts.en:
Annet N. lives in the Kyebando neighborhood of the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is married and has four children, all of whom are in school.   She also takes care of her father. She lives in a home that she owns and she has access to electricity and piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include school fees and feeding the family.

Annet has a business of selling charcoal.  She has been in this business for ten years, and she works seven days a week. She sells her products at retail prices from her home.  Her main business challenge is transportation.  Her goals and aspirations for her business are to start selling on a wholesale basis only.

Annet has requested a loan of 300,000 UGX from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy bags of charcoal to sell.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine K. is forty-seven years old, a widow, and has three children between the ages of twenty-four and fifteen. She hopes to give them a quality education to the university level. Her business is located at the busy Mwingi market, though she is served by the Thika branch office. Thika is the region in Kenya known for production of pineapples. 

Josephine operates a retail shop. She has been in this business for three years now. She says that this business is profitable and the major challenge she has is financial constraints. However, she works very hard to keep her business doing well. 

She is using her loan of 10,000 KES to resupply her stock to be able to meet her customers' needs. She hopes to have a wholesale shop in the future and even build her own residential house. She describes herself as hardworking, responsible and innovative.

loans.use: To buy sugar, cooking oil, detergents, etc. to sell.

loans.name: Kibibi

texts.en:
Kibibi is a married woman.  She has four children, three of whom attend school; the other one is still too young for school. She owns a house that has access to electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family. 

For over seven years, Kibibi has operated a cloth-selling shop where she sells Kikois (an African version of a sarong) and shoes. She sells her goods to her neighbours and passersby. Seasonal weather is a challenge; during the hot summer months, demand for heavy clothes is lower. 

With the KES 20,000 loan she has requested, Kibibi wants to purchase a bale of Kikois and shoes for resale. She hopes to expand her business in the future.  She decided to join Yehu because of its minimal saving requirements.

loans.use: to purchase a bale of Kikois and shoes for resale

loans.name: Rose

texts.en: Rose C. is 27 years old and is married to a police man. She has 4 children, one of whom goes to school.  She is currently in the business of selling tomatoes at the market and is requesting a loan to stock more tomatoes to sell.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a shop.

loans.use: to stock more tomatoes to sell

loans.name: Darisuren

texts.en:
Darisuren B. is 44 years old.  She lives with her husband and son in a ger – a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent – in the province of Huvsgul, in Mongolia. Her son attends a local high school, and her husband is currently unemployed. 

Darisuren operates a tailoring business out of her home. She has been working on her own since 1994, after having gained experience working in a clothing factory since 1983. She has made much progress with her business over the years and has gained many permanent customers. She sews a variety of items according to her customers' tastes and orders. She has used her earnings to support her family. In the future, she plans to have her own workplace next to her home. She is requesting a 500,000 MNT loan to purchase a new sewing machine for her business.

loans.use: to purchase a new sewing machine

loans.name: Christine

texts.en:
Christine N. lives in the Mulago neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is married and has 3 children, two of whom are in school.  She lives in a home that she rents, and has access to electricity and piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include school fees. 

Christine has been in the tailoring business for 2 years, and she works 7 days a week. She has a retail shop in Mulago market. She also generates additional income by selling fried ground nuts and popcorn. Her main business challenge is transportation.  

Christine has requested a loan of 400,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more clothing materials.  Her goal for her business is to improve her standard of living by owning an electric sewing machine.

loans.use: to buy more clothing materials

loans.name: Jane Wairimu

texts.en: Jane is 38 years old, and has 3 children with her husband, John M.. She has practiced farming in Njabini town since 2002.  She heard about KADET LTD through its field officers, and this will be her second loan.  She paid her first loan of KES 40,000 in good time.  She plans to use her new loan to buy fertilizer and pesticides for her farm. In the future, Jane is planning to buy another piece of land on which she will establish a dairy farm.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and pesticides for her farm.

loans.name: Gerelchimeg

texts.en:
Gerelchimeg S. is 43 years old and lives with her husband and two sons in the Huvsgul province of Mongolia. She and her family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Her oldest son, age 22, is a university student and her youngest son, age 17, currently attends a local high school. 

Gerelchimeg and her husband operate a raw-materials trading business in a small wooden pavilion. They began the business in 2004 and have gained  experience as traders. In the future, Gerelchimeg plans to upgrade her workplace by trading the pavilion for a large container with capacity for 20 tons. Her business earnings have allowed her to pay her son's tuition fees. Gerelchimeg is a modest and hardworking person, who is seeking  to increase her working capital.  She has requested a 1,500,000 MNT loan for her  trading business.

loans.use: To buy more raw materials to sell

loans.name: Ayaa

texts.en: Ayaa M. currently earns a living by selling beer and by offering "boda-boda" taxi service on  her motorbike.  She is requesting a loan to stock more crates of beer to sell.  Ayaa is 23 years old and married to a businessman.  She has 3 children, who all attend school.  With the extra profits generated from this loan, she hopes to be able to open up a shop.

loans.use: To stock more crates of beer to sell

loans.name: Madrona

texts.en:
Madrona Q. is from the village of Kabatangan, Wao, Lanao del Sur. She is 58 years old. Madrona is married and has 8 adult-aged children. To make a living, Madrona owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling daily-use products such as shampoo, soap, toothpaste, canned goods and packaged food. She also buys and sells vegetables, such as squash. Madrona has been engaged in her business for more than 10 years and earns approximately 10000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Madrona joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Madrona has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Madrona is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This loan will be the 4th loan taken out by Madrona from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory

loans.name: Peter Kuria

texts.en: Peter has farmed in Njabini town for the last three years.  He is 49 years old, married to Mary Wanjiku and they have three  children. He heard about KADET through the field staff and this will be his second loan.  He paid his first loan of 25,000 Kenyan shillings well and in good time.  He plans to use this loan to buy another dairy cow which will increase his milk output for his customers who are increasing daily.

loans.use: To buy a dairy cow

loans.name: Micheline

texts.fr: O. Micheline est née le 21 Février 1978 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Micheline vit depuis sa naissance au quartier Adogléta à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Micheline est mariée et est mère de trois enfants, tous scolarisés. Le couple a un autre enfant à leur charge, en plus de leurs enfants. Micheline aide son mari à assurer les dépenses de la famille, grâce au revenu que lui procure son activité. Micheline n’a pas été à l’école. Pour faire face à ses besoins et nourrir sa famille, Micheline vend diverses sortes de savons, mais aussi d’autres articles dont les condiments, dans sa boutique située à son domicile. Micheline se ravitaille à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. C’est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, qui a toujours bien remboursé ses crédits. Micheline désire augmenter son fonds de roulement et mieux répondre à la demande de sa clientèle ; raison pour laquelle Micheline sollicite un septième crédit. Plus tard, Micheline ambitionne acquérir sa propre parcelle.
texts.en:
O. Micheline was born on February 21, 1978 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin.  Since birth, she has lived in the Adogléta district in Cotonou.  She is married and the mother of three children, who are all in school.  The couple have another child in their care in addition to their own children.  Micheline helps her husband to cover family expenses, thanks to the revenue from her business.  

Micheline did not attend school.  To meet her needs and to feed the family, she sells a variety of soaps but also other items, including condiments, in her shop located in her home.  She stocks up at Dantokpa, the international market of Benin. 

She is a previous client of ALIDé who has always repaid her loans.  She would like to increase her working capital and to respond better to customer demands.  For these reasons, Micheline is requesting a seventh loan.  Later on, she her ambition is to acquire her own plot of land.

loans.use: Buying various personal care products

loans.name: John Ngure

texts.en: John has farmed in Njabini town for the last five years.  He is 62 years old, married to Tabitha Mukami and they have four children. He heard about KADET through KADET staff and this will be his first loan.  He plans to use the cash to plant more potatoes on his farm during this planting season.  In the future, John hopes to buy more land and start practicing large scale farming.

loans.use: To plant more potatoes on his farm

loans.name: Handtseren

texts.en:
Handtseren T. is a 53-year-old widow who lives with her two children in an apartment in Baganuur, one of the remote districts of Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia's capital city. Her son, age 14, attends local secondary school, while her daughter, age 29, helps out with her business.

Handtseren currently operates a clothing retail business in her community. She has been in this business for the past four years and has built a stable and successful operation. She has proven herself a reliable customer to the bank, always paying her loan in full and on time. She needs more funds in order to increase her working capital. Handtseren is a very modest and hardworking woman. She says, "I am planning to save enough money for my son's future education costs and wish my daughter could get a decent job." She is requesting a 2,000,000 tugrik loan to purchase more winter clothing items in order to increase her working capital.

loans.use: To purchase more winter clothing

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
Maria V. Navuga lives in the Kyebando neighborhood of the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is single and has three children, all of whom are in school. Maria lives in a home that she owns. She has access to electricity and piped water. Her major monthly expenses include school fees and feeding the family.

Maria has a business selling charcoal. She has been in this business for five years, and she works 7 days out of every week. Maria sells her products retail from home. She has requested a loan of 300,000/- Ugandan shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bags of charcoal. The main business challenge for Maria is transportation. Her aspiration for her business is to buy a plot of land so that she can have a permanent business premises.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal

loans.name: Emily

texts.en: Emily T.'s main source of income comes from providing jeepney (a multi-purpose vehicle) services to local community members. She is 42 years old, married and has three school-aged children. They are from the village of Amoyong, Wao, Lanao del Sur. Emily has been in her business for over five years and earns approximately 10,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month. In 2009, Emily joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Emily has successfully repaid a previous loan of 13,000 PHP from HSPFI which was used to purchase tools needed to provide her service. Emily is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase tools needed for the maintenance of her jeepney. This will be her fifth loan from HSPFI. She plans to use additional income to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase tools needed for the maintenance of her jeepney

loans.name: Lhagvadorj

texts.en: Lhagvadorj P. is 44 years old and he lives with his wife and two children in the Huvsgul province of Mongolia. His family lives in a ger (a traditional Mongolian nomadic home tent). His wife works as a teacher at the local school and his daughter, age 18, currently lives in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia, where she studies at university. His youngest son, age 14, attends a local secondary school. Lhagvadorj worked as a master in the forest company between 1988 and 1995, and, since 2003, he has been operating a wood production business. He has owned his carpentry business for many years and over this long time he has earned the loyalty of his customers because of the quality of his work and service. His earnings have enabled him not only to pay for his daughter's tuition fees, but also to start building a new house that will be used as a workplace for his wood production in the yard. Lhagvadorj is requesting a 1,600,000 tugrik loan in order to increase his working capital.

loans.use: To buy more wood

loans.name: Naranchimeg

texts.en: Naranchimeg D. is 48 years old and lives with her husband and two children in Huvsgul province of Mongolia. She lives with her family in a ger (a traditional Mongolian housing tent). Her two children both attend a local secondary school. Her husband works as a sawyer in the local firewood market. Naranchimeg operates a grocery out of a stall at the local market. She started her business in 2002 after working at a grocery store as a salesperson between 1985 and 2002. Over the years, she has built a stable and successful business operation. She hopes to expand her business by enlarging her workplace. With this loan, she is planning to increase her product line. Currently, she sells a variety of foodstuffs in her small wooden pavilion. She hopes to improve her workplace by making it a bigger space in the future. Naranchimeg is requesting a 2,000,000 tugrik loan to purchase a large quantity of foodstuffs at wholesale prices to sell back as a retailer and to expand her product line.

loans.use: To purchase large quantity of foodstuffs

loans.name: Lolango Plus Group

texts.en:
Bedi L., aged 38 and married, is the president of the Community Bank named “Lolango Plus,” which consists of 21 members united in solidarity to receive loans from Kiva through IMF HOPE RDC with the goal of developing their businesses. 

Bedi started her business in 1999. She has been running a restaurant located west of the city of Kinshasa. She is a loyal client of IMF HOPE RDC who has already received five different loans and has repaid them properly. 

She intends to use the next loan to increase the stock of her restaurant by buying one sack of flour, two bags of sugar, and beans with the aim of increasing profits. Each week, her business brings in a profit of $60. 

Her ambition is to open a big restaurant in her area. Bedi has four children whose ages are between 8 and 20 years old. All of them go to school.

loans.use: Increasing the stock of her restaurant by buying flour, beans and other goods

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Liza

texts.en: Liza C. is from the village of Amoyong, Wao, Lanao del Sur. She is 31 years old. Liza is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Liza runs a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling daily-use products such as shampoo, soap, toothpaste, canned goods and junk foods in the local community. Liza has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 8,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2010, Liza joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Liza has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Liza is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be the second loan taken out by Liza from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and as working capital

loans.name: Oyungerel

texts.en:
Oyungerel T. is 32 years old and lives with her two children in Arvaiheer city of the Uvurhangai province, Mongolia. She and her family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent, in her sister's yard. Her two children attend a local secondary school. 

Oyungerel manages a clothing trade business in her town. She started her clothing business in 2009 with the help of her sister and since then, has built a stable and successful operation. Before she moved to her current town, she used to live and work in the Uyanga sub province with her two children. Her sister, Tungalag, brought them to Arvaiheer in order to improve their quality of life. 

After growing her business in this short period, her success has enabled her to operate her business individually. For the future, Oyungerel hopes to continue to grow her business and says, "All I want is to support my children and raise them to become a good people. I try my best to make success with my new business." 

She is requesting a 1,000,000 Mongolian tugriks loan to purchase more winter clothes for the upcoming cold season.

loans.use: To purchase more winter clothes

loans.name: Mariam

texts.fr:
Madame Mariam S. est une femme mariée de 34 ans et mère de 4 enfants qui vit dans une famille monogame avec son mari et ses enfants  dans le quartier Hérémakono Nord de la ville de Bougouni (région de Sikasso). 
Elle a vite abandonné l’école au profit des activités génératrices de revenus notamment l’achat vente des fruits et légumes tels les bananes.  Elle mène cette activité depuis plus de 9 ans, ce qui explique sa  bonne maîtrise cette  activité. 
Elle s’approvisionne dans la commune de Sido et dans les ses villages environnants auprès des producteurs. Sido est une commune rurale située à 25 kilomètres de Bougouni. Elle a appris cette activité dès son âge auprès de sa cousine.
Après des prêts solidaires avec une association de son quartier, elle décide de venir au prêt individuel et est à son quatrième, après avoir remboursé correctement tous les prêts antérieurs. Depuis maintenant six ans cette femmes collabore  avec Soro Yiriwaso.
Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter puis vendre des bananes dans les différents quartiers et marchés de aussi bien que devant la mairie  de la commune urbaine de Bougouni.
Mariam espère réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 40.000 FCFA. Avec ces bénéfices elle envisage agrandir son entreprise.
texts.en:
Mrs. Mariam S. is a 34-year-old married woman and the mother of 4 children. She lives in a monogamous family with her husband and children in the Hérémakono Nord district of the town of Bougouni (Sikasso region). 

She abandoned school early on in favor of income-generating activities, notably the buying and selling of fruits and vegetables such as bananas. She has been in this business for more than 9 years, which explains her good command of this activity. She gets her supplies from producers in the community of Sido and in surrounding villages. Sido is a rural community located 25 kilometers from Bougouni. She learned this business at a young age from her cousin.

After a few solidarity loans with an association in her district, she decided to get her first individual loan. This is her fourth individual loan, after having successfully repaid all previous loans. This woman has been collaborating with Soro Yiriwaso for six years now.

She plans to use her loan to buy and then sell bananas in different districts and markets and also in front of the town hall of the urban community of Bougouni. With this loan, Mariam hopes to make a monthly profit of 40,000 CFA francs. With these profits, she plans to expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase bananas

loans.name: Gladys

texts.en: Gladys B. is from the village of Francfort, Bumbaran, Lanao del Sur. She is 33 years old. Gladys is married and has an infant child. To make a living, Gladys runs a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling canned goods, biscuits and junk food in the local community. Gladys has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 5,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2010, Gladys joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Gladys is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the first loan taken out by Gladys from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Mary Jane

texts.en:
Mary Jane Q. is from the town of Sto. Niño. She is 46 years old. Mary Jane is married and has three children. To make a living, Mary Jane plants and harvests rice for sale. Mary Jane also runs a small sari-sari (variety) store, where she sells soy sauce, biscuits and other kinds of products.

Mary Jane joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Mary Jane has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. 

Mary Jane is requesting a new loan of 15,000 Philippines pesos, which will be used to purchase seeds and fertilizers. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's living conditions.

loans.use: To purchase seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Jennifer

texts.en: Jennifer B. is from the village of Francfort, Bumbaran, Lanao del Sur. She is 25 years old. Jennifer is single. To make a living, Jennifer runs a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling daily-use products such as shampoo, soap, toothpaste, canned goods and junk food in the local community. Jennifer has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 5,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2010, Jennifer joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jennifer is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell and as working capital. This will be the first loan taken out by Jennifer from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell and for working capital

loans.name: Kyosimbaonanya Kikajjo-Kampala Group

texts.en: Maureen K. is 42 years old, has four children and leads a loan group called Kyosimbaonanya Kikajjo. For the last four years, she has made a living by running a small grocery store in the town of Namasuba. She started this business by investing a small amount of money she earned by farming, and today earns 100,000 shillings a month from the store and a small maize mill that she operates. Maureen has applied for this loan because she would like to expand her shop by buying more items to sell to her customers.

loans.use: to buy items to sell from a small store

loans.name: Juvy

texts.en:
Juvy A. is from the town of Sto. Niño. She is 40 years old. Juvy is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Juvy plants and harvests rice for sale. Juvy wishes for her children to finish college and have bright futures. 

Juvy joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Juvy has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. 

Juvy is requesting a new loan of 15,000 Philippines pesos, which will be used to purchase farm inputs like seeds and fertilizers. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children.

loans.use: To purchase farm inputs like seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Isfandiyor

texts.ru: Ахтамов Исфандиёр проживает в городе Душанбе. Возраст, 25 лет. Женат, имеет одного ребенка. Жена, домохозяйка. Сам Исфандиёр имеет высшее образование, экономист. По профессии не работает. Сейчас у него дилерский центр, где он пополняет балансы, продает сим - карты и карты для пополнения балансов. Этим видом деятельности занимается уже 6 лет. Кредит берет для покупки сим - карт.
texts.en: Istafandiyor A. lives in the city of Dushanbe.  He is 25 years old, married and has one child.  His wife is a homemaker.  Istafandiyor has a higher education, as an economist.  He does not work in that field.  Currently, Istafandiyor has a dealer center, where he refills usage balances, sells SIM cards and cards for refilling balances.  He has been involved in this business for 6 years.  He is requesting this loan for the purchase of SIM cards.

loans.use: Purchase of SIM cards

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: For family expenses

loans.name: Bulenga Twekembe Group 1-Mpigi

texts.en: It is now more than 10 years since 36-year-old N. Hadijah began her timber product sales business in Bulenga-Mpigi. Hadija is contentedly married with four kids. 120,000 shillings is what this business generates weekly for this lady, who has all along relied on self-motivation, resoluteness and will power to achieve growth in her dealings. With this loan she wants to purchase more timber for resale. She belongs to 'Bulenga Twekembe' group-Mpigi.

loans.use: The purchase of more timber for resale

loans.name: Lilibeth

texts.en: Lilibeth P. is from the village of Kilikili, Wao, Lanao del Sur. She is 29 years old. Lilibeth is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Lilibeth runs a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling daily-use products such as shampoo, soap, toothpaste, canned goods and junk food in the local community. Lilibeth has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 5,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2010, Lilibeth joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lilibeth is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be the first loan taken out by Lilibeth from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and as  working capital

loans.name: Hortense Julienne S.

texts.fr: O. Hortense Julienne S. est née le 12 Avril 1978 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Mariée à SAÏZONOU Euphrem, Hortense Julienne est mère d’un enfant qui est scolarisé. Le couple a un autre enfant à leur charge. Il y a juste un an que la famille s’est installée au quartier Yénawa à Cotonou. Hortense Julienne aide son mari à assurer les diverses charges familiales, grâce au revenu de son activité. Hortense Julienne a arrêté l’école au cours secondaire, puis s’est consacrée à la vente de savons en cartons et aussi des biscuits et des produits alimentaires en cartons. Hortense Julienne s’approvisionne au marché Gbogbanou à Cotonou, et vend ses produits à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. C’est la deuxième fois que Hortense Julienne sollicite auprès de ALIDé un crédit, en vue d’augmenter son fonds de roulement et d’accroître sa clientèle, ce qui lui permettra de se faire plus de revenus.
texts.en: Hortense Julienne S. O. was born on 12 April 1978 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin.  Married to Euphrem Saizonou, Hortense Julienne is the mother of one child who attends school.  The couple has another child they look after.  They have only been living in the Yénawa neighborhood in Cotonou for one year.  Hortense Julienne helps her husband manage the various family expenses thanks to the profits of her business.  Hortense Julienne quit school at the secondary level, then devoted herself to the sale of boxes of soap and also boxes of crackers and basic foodstuffs.  Hortense Julienne buys her supply at the Gbogbanou market in Cotonou and sells her products in Dantokpa, the international market of Benin.  This is the second time that Hortense Julienne has requested a loan from ALIDé.  She is looking to increase her working capital and increase her clientele which will allow her to gain more profits.

loans.use: Buying boxes of soap and crackers

loans.name: Kabunyansi Agalyawamu Savings And Credit, Mubende Group

texts.en:
Hard-working N. Edison has over two years been operating a cattle-fattening farm in Kamuseenene, Mubende where he sells cows to earn a living at the periodic markets that take place around the area in western Uganda. In this business, he directly purchases the livestock and then rears it for some time on his farm till he finds it ready market, where he supplies to butchers and restaurants. He further operates agricultural farming from which he generates income out of food crops, produce that he sells such as beans, maize and more.

His main drawback in the course of doing this business has been unstable prices on the market and low capital input. With hard work and efficient customer care skills, he has managed to keep his business going. In a month, he makes profits to the tune of 320,000 Ugandan shillings. 

His future plans are to fully expand the business transactions and do farm restocking with more livestock which will earn him more revenue to pay for his children’s education requirements and improve their standard of living. With this loan, he anticipates great strides in achieving this dream and restocking more cattle for resale.

Edison belongs to Kabunyansi Agalyawamu Savings and Credit, Mubende.

loans.use: purchase of more cattle for fattening on the farm

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth P. is from the town of Sto. Niño. She is 39 years old. Elizabeth is married and has four children. Her eldest child is 8 years old while the youngest is only 2. She is a farmer and a hog-grower. She helps her husband, who is also a farmer, maintain their rice farm. She also helps in selling their harvest. Elizabeth also does her best to keep the pigs she grows healthy. 

Elizabeth is requesting a loan of 15,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) from CEVI to be used for her farm. She will buy seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs with her loan. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: To purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs

loans.name: Luvuno

texts.en:
Luvuno is a married woman with four children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food. 

She operates a firewood selling business, a vegetable stall and a workshop. Her potential customers are neighbors and passersby. Luvuno faces a challenge of seasonality. During the rainy season, there is plenty of supply of vegetables; hence, she makes less profits. She hopes to expand and supply to more clients in the future.

With the 60,000 Kenyan shillings, she wants to purchase a bundle of firewood and tools for her workshop business. She decided to join Yehu to get a loan to expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase a bundle of firewood and tools for her workshop business

loans.name: Stella

texts.en: Stella is a single mother of two children aged 5 and 9 years. She is 30 years old and looks after a family of three people. She lives in Fort Portal, Uganda in her own house. She says the only present she can give to her children as a mother in this generation is education so that they can be responsible citizens in the future. Stella operates a retail shop and has been in the business for the last four years. However, she says fluctuation of prices affect her business plans and expectations. This is her sixth loan from HOFOKAM and she intends to pay school fees for her children.

loans.use: To pay school fees for her children.

loans.name: Mireille Clarisse

texts.fr: G. Mireille Clarisse est née en Décembre 1983 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Mariée à OUSSOUKPEVI Rodrigue, Mireille Clarisse n’a pas encore d’enfant. Mireille Clarisse s’est installée depuis une dizaine d’année au quartier Sènadé à Cotonou, où elle vit avec son mari. Le couple assure ensemble les dépenses du foyer. Mireille Clarisse a arrêté l’école au cours secondaire. Depuis près de sept ans, Mireille Clarisse vend des céréales (maïs, riz, haricot) et des divers (biscuits, bombons, sucre, lait, etc.) dans sa boutique size à son domicile. De façon secondaire, Mireille Clarisse vend des cartes de recharges téléphoniques. C’est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin que Mireille Clarisse achète ses produits.  Mireille Clarisse a déjà bénéficié une fois de crédit auprès de ALIDé et a bien effectué le remboursement. Face à la demande un peu plus importante de sa clientèle, Mireille Clarisse sollicite auprès de ALIDé, un second prêt, en vue de rehausser le niveau de son activité et de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle.
texts.en: Mireille Clarisse G. was born in December of 1983 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin.  Married to Rodrigue Oussoukpevi, Mireille Clarisse does not yet have a child.  Mireille Clarisse settled in the Sènadé neighborhood in Cotounou about twelve years ago, where she now lives with her husband.  The couple works together to secure the household expenses.  Mireille Clarisse quit school at the secondary level.  For nearly seven years, Mireille Clarisse has sold cereals (cornmeal, rice, beans) and various foodstuffs (cookies, candy, sugar, milk, etc.) in a small shop next to her home.  She also sells rechargeable telephone cards.  It is in Dantokpa, the international market of Benin, that Mireille Clarisse purchases her products.  Mireille Clarisse has already benefited once from a loan from ALIDé and repaid it in full.  In the face of greater needs of her clientele, Mireille Clarisse is asking for a second loan from ALIDé, looking to enhance the quality of her business and better satisfy her clientele.

loans.use: Buying sacks of cereals and various food items (cookies, candy, etc.)

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en:
Ruth N. lives in the Nakulabye neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is married and has five children, three of whom are in school.  

Ruth has a business of selling charcoal. She has been in this business for over 10 years and she works five days out of every week. Ruth sells her products at the market, by means of wholesale and retail.    

Ruth has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bags of charcoal. The main business challenges for Ruth include transportation and thieves.  

Her goals and aspirations are to own a delivery van and to educate her children up to university. Ruth lives in a home that she rents. She has access to electricity and piped water. Her major monthly expenses include school fees and rent.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal

loans.name: Jinnilyn

texts.en:
Jinnilyn L. is from the town of Sto. Niño. She is 36 years old. Jinnilyn is married and has four children. Her kids are aged 11, 10, 4 and 3. She and her husband are both farmers. They plant and harvest rice crops for sale. Jinnilyn also acquired piglets she is now raising. She is working hard to help provide for her family and sustain her children's education. She dreams to see them finish college and have bright futures.

Jinnilyn joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jinnilyn has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Jinnilyn is requesting a new loan of 10,000 Philippines pesos, which will be used to purchase fertilizers, piglets and feeds. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers, piglets and feeds

loans.name: Adama

texts.fr:
Monsieur Adama Koné est un homme marié de 30 et père de 3 enfants. Il vit avec sa femme et ses enfants dans une famille traditionnelle élargie dans le quartier Torakabougou de Bougouni.
Il  fréquenta l’école coranique pendant des années. Afin de s’inserrer dans le tissu économique, il commença les activités génératrices de revenus telles  la vente de chaussures, de pagnes, de tissus, mais  cela sans réussite.
Alors, il décida d’accompagner son père pour apprendre le processus d’achat et de vente de céréales. Avec une expérience de plus de 5 ans, il maîtrise son activité. 
Dans le souci d’agrandir davantage son entreprise, il décida de collaborer avec Soro Yiriwaso avec qui il est à son cinquième prêt individuel, après avoir bien remboursé, les quatre prêts précédents. 
Il s’approvisionne à Bougouni et dans les villages  environnants auprès  des producteurs.
Avec ce nouveau prêt Monsieur Adama Koné envisage acheter, des tonnes de céréales. La vente se fait au marché de Torakabougou de Bougouni et une partie est vendue dans les différents villages les jours de marché hebdomadaire en détail, en demi gros, au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle diverse et variée. 
Monsieur Adama Koné envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 80 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour rembourser le prêt et investir le reste dans les activités.
texts.en:
Mr. Adama Koné is a 30-year-old married man and father of three children. He lives with his wife and children in a traditional extended family in the neighborhood of Torakabougou, in Bougouni.

He attended Koranic school for several years. In order to enter the workforce, he started earning a living through various activities such as selling shoes, pagnes, and fabrics, but without success.

He then opted to work alongside his father to learn the trade of buying and selling grain. With over five years of experience, he now had a good command of his work. 

Wishing to further expand his business, he joined the Soro Yiriwaso micro-finance institution and is now seeking his fifth individual loan, having repaid four previous loans without incident.

He gets his stocks from farmers in Bougouni and surrounding villages. With this new loan, Mr. Koné plans to buy tons of grain. Some will be sold at the Torakabougou market in Bougouni, and some in various towns at the weekly market, retail or wholesale, for cash or credit, to a mixed clientele.

Mr. Koné expects to earn a monthly profit of 80,000 FCFA, which will be used to repay the loan, the remainder to be reinvested in his business.

loans.use: To purchase cereals

loans.name: Erinest

texts.en:
Erinest is a 47-year-old man who is married to a peasant farmer and together they have eight children. He looks after a family of ten people and lives in Fort Portal, Uganda in his own family house. His major dreams for the family are basically to educate his children and improve the household income.
Erinest is a tailor and has been in the business for 25 years now. Before being a tailor, Erinest was a farmer but opted to change his business sector to tailoring. He says he is doing better in terms of income generation than he would if he was still a farmer. He intends to use the loan proceeds to pay school fees for the children.

loans.use: To pay school fees for the children.

loans.name: Fatima

texts.fr: O. Fatima est mariée à MOSSOURO Moussibaou et est mère de quatre enfants, tous scolarisés. Seulement, deux des enfants sont à la charge du couple. Depuis près de vingt huit ans, Fatima s’est installée au quartier Suru-Léré à Cotonou (capitale économique du Bénin), où elle vit avec sa famille. Fatima assure avec son mari les différentes charges de la famille. Fatima a très peu fréquenté l’école. Depuis environs quinze ans, Fatima prépare et vend de la nourriture (riz accompagné de sauce aux tomates, et aussi de la bouillie de maïs) à Kowégbo à Cotonou ; ce qui lui permet de nourrir sa famille et de satisfaire ses propres besoins. Fatima achète ses produits à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. C’est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, ayant obtenu cinq crédits qui ont été tous bien remboursés. Fatima désire augmenter le volume de son activité et accroître sa clientèle et donc son revenu ; raison pour laquelle Fatima sollicite un autre prêt.
texts.en: Fatima O. is married to Moussibaou Mossouro and has four children, all in school. Only two of the children are in the care of the couple. For close to twenty-eight years, Fatima has lived in the Suru-Léré area of Cotonou (the economic capital of Benin), along with her family. Fatima provides for the family with her husband. She has had very little schooling. For about fifteen years, Fatima has prepared and sold food (rice accompanied by tomato sauce, and maize 'bouillie' - a type of porridge) at Kowégbo in Cotonou; this has allowed her to feed her family and meet her own needs. Fatima buys her supplies at Dantokpa, the international market in Benin. She is a longstanding client of ALIDÉ (one of Kiva's field partners), having obtained five loans that were all repaid properly. Fatima wants to raise the volume of her business and increase her clientele and thus her income; this is why she is seeking another loan.

loans.use: To buy bags of rice and cans of peanut oil

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: This Kiva borrower is a 35-year-old single woman living with her parents. She has owned a cattle farm in her town since 2006. And she has been working in this field for the past 13 years on a local farm. She produces dairy products such as milk. She helps her father who works as a farmer in the household. Today, she is requesting a loan of $1000 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase fodder for her cattle to get a good quality of milk, especially before the winter season. This is because it is very popular in Lebanon to buy milk from cattle farms and make special Lebanese dairy products.

loans.use: To purchase fodder

loans.name: Adidjatou

texts.fr: A. Adidjatou est née le 15 Septembre 1963. C’est une veuve qui n’a pas d’enfant. Depuis près de sept ans, Adidjatou vit donc seule au quartier Sènadé à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Adidjatou arrive à faire face à ses différents besoins, grâce au revenu que lui procure son activité. Adidjatou n’a jamais fréquenté l’école. Il y a une vingtaine d’année que Adidjatou mène comme activité la vente de divers produits de soins (savons de toilette et de lessive) à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. C’est également dans le même marché que Adidjatou achète ses produits. Adidjatou a déjà obtenu un crédit auprès de ALIDé et a bien effectué le remboursement. Face à la demande de plus en plus grandissante de sa clientèle, Adidjatou désire augmenter son fonds de roulement et élever le niveau de son activité afin de mieux répondre aux exigences de sa clientèle. C'est la raison pour laquelle Adidjatou sollicite pour la deuxième fois l'appui financier de ALIDé.
texts.en: Adidjatou A. was born on 15 September 1963. She is a widow and has no children. For close to seven years, Adidjatou has thus lived alone in the Sènadé area of Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Adidjatou is able to meet her various needs thanks to the income provided by her business. She never went to school. For about twenty years, Adidjatou has run a business selling various toiletry products (soaps and detergents) at Dantokpa, the international market in Benin. She buys her goods at the same market. Adidjatou has already obtained one previous loan through ALIDÉ (one of Kiva's field partners) and was able to repay it properly. Faced with the growing demands of her clientele, Adidjatou wants to increase her working capital and raise the level of her business in order to better respond to the needs of her customers. This is the reason why Adidjatou, for the second time, is seeking financial support through ALIDÉ.

loans.use: To buy boxes of soap and detergent

loans.name: John

texts.en: John is a teacher at one of the high schools in Fort Portal, Uganda. He is 40 years old and a father of two children aged 10 and 9 years. In his home, he lives with five people and he is the breadwinner for his family. However, for most parents and guardians in the country, school fees have become an issue that most of them would find very difficult to meet on their own without credit support, given the income levels and family responsibilities. John falls in that category and he wants this loan to enable him pay school fees for his children.

loans.use: To pay school fees for his children.

loans.name: Fatimatou

texts.fr: Madame Fatimatou F. est une femme de 39 ans qui habite dans la localité de Baye Laye à Guediawaye. Elle est mariée et mère de 5 enfants. Madame F. a choisi l’activité de commerce dans le but d’acquérir des revenus et d’aider son mari dans la gestion des charges familiales. Depuis  10 ans elle évoluait  dans la vente de friperie  dans un marché du quartier. Elle est même  parvenue à acquérir une cantine dans le marché et s’adonne a la vente de tissus. Elle est membre de la caisse de Baye Laye depuis juillet 2003. Elle a déjà remboursé 4 prêts  antérieurs. Elle sollicite un crédit de 500 000 frs prévu pour renforcer le stock de tissus dans sa cantine. Son souhait est de développer son activité de commerce et renforcer son épargne dans le but d’effectuer des voyages à l’extérieur pour l’intérêt  de son activité de commerce.
texts.en: Ms. Fatimatou F. is a 39-year-old woman who lives in the Baye Laye area in Guediawaye. She is married and has 5 children. Ms. F. chose to start a business in order to earn an income and help her husband provide for the family. For 10 years, she has developed a business selling second-hand clothing at a market in her locality. She has even managed to acquire a booth at the market and has devoted herself to selling fabric. She has been a member of the Baye Laye local fund since July 2003, and has already repaid 4 previous loans. She is seeking a loan of 500,000 Frs meant to increase the stock of fabric in her stall. Her hope is to develop her business and strengthen her savings with the goal of being able to travel more widely for the benefit of her business.

loans.use: To buy fabric

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 26-year-old single man living with his parents and five siblings. He has owned a cattle farm in his town since 2007. He works independently on his farm. He produces dairy products, such as milk, and he delivers the products to some markets and also upon request of clients. He helps his father in collaboration with his brothers to provide better living conditions for the family. 

Today, he is requesting to borrow $1,000 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase fodder for his cattle to get a good quality of milk, especially before the winter season because it is very typical in Lebanon to buy milk from cattle farms and make special Lebanese dairy products.

loans.use: To purchase fodder

loans.name: Rosebell

texts.en: Rosebell is a 45-year-old woman living in Fort Portal, Uganda. She is a single mother of two children. She lives in a family of seven people in her own house. Her family dream is to have her children well educated so that they can have a better future. She has a retail shop and a restaurant as her business lines of activities. She has been operating them for the last seven years. She says, though, that her dream is to go wholesale in the near future so that she can reap big in term of profits. Rosebell intends to use the loan funds to pay school fees for her children.

loans.use: To pay school fees for her children.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary B. lives in the Nakulabye neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is married and has three children, all of whom are in school.  Mary has a business of a clinic. She has been in this business for over 10 years and she works 7 days out of every week. Mary sells her products from home, by means of retail. Mary has requested a loan of 2,000,000/= Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more boxes of drugs. She also generates additional income through poultry farming. The main business challenge(s) for Mary include transportation and defaulters.  Her goals and aspirations for her business are to own a fully stocked clinic and to educate her children up to university. Mary lives in a home that she owns with access to electricity and piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include school fees and feeding the family.

loans.use: To buy more boxes of drugs

loans.name: Jumaboy

texts.en:
Jumaboy is married with four children. He owns a business selling household goods. Jumaboy is full of ideas. He has rich experience working in this business. Moreover, he is very enthusiastic about his own small enterprise and has a good attitude. Jumaboy sets high goals and takes daily action to achieve them. He has been in this business for 10 years. Jumaboy would like to get a loan of $3,000 USD to increase his working capital. He believes financial assistance will support him in his endeavors. He is determined to work on his entrepreneurial dreams to make them a reality, understanding that real success and wealth take time. Jumaboy is hoping to generate more profit and provide for his children, who study in school now. 
 
More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing household goods in order to increase the range of goods

loans.name: Janeffer

texts.en:
Janeffer is a poultry farmer from Murang'a town in central Kenya where she has been farming for 18 years. She sells her poultry at a local market. She is 45 years old and married with 5 children, 2 teenagers and 3 adults. Two of the children are currently attending school.
